DEBATE.TITLE: STATES GRANTS (EDUCATION ASSISTANCE-PARTICIPATION AND EQUITY) BILL 1983

PROCTEXT.PARA: [COGNATE BILLS:
STATES GRANTS (SCHOOLS ASSISTANCE) BILL 1983
STATES GRANTS (TERTIARY EDUCATION ASSISTANCE) AMENDMENT BILL 1983]
Debate resumed from 8 December 1983, on motion by Senator Gietzelt:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RYAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Education and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-Mr President, I conclude my remarks on the second reading debate of the States Grants (Education Assistance-Participation and Equity) Bill, the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Bill and the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill by saying that the Government will not accept any amendments to this legislation. They are money Bills and it is important for them to be completed forthwith.

SPEECH.PARA: I foreshadow to the Australian Democrats the Government's intentions with regard to strengthening the appeal procedures. The Australian Democrats suggested to the Government that we should consider making decisions of the Commonwealth Schools Commission with regard to categories of schools and income testing appealable to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. However, having discussed this matter with the Schools Commission and with Senator Macklin, we have now decided that a more appropriate, more effective strengthening of the existing appeals procedures would be to establish within the Schools Commission an independent tribunal, independently chaired, similar in character to the tertiary education assistance scheme tribunal or the Social Security Appeals Tribunal. Such a tribunal would provide expertise in the matters under consideration and would be an avenue of appeal other than that currently available to the Commission itself.

There is already a very extensive appeals mechanism in place, and appellants who are dissatisfied with that form of appeal can seek the protection of the Ombudsman's Act and the Federal Court of Australia. Senator Macklin has indicated on behalf of the Australian Democrats that he supports this concept of independent appeals. Once this matter is approved by the Cabinet the Government can proceed forthwith to set up the tribunal and the necessary legislative action can be taken early in the new year. That matter is foreshadowed, but I conclude my remarks by indicating that no amendments will be accepted by the Government.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Temporary Chairman, the States Grants (Education Assistance-Participation and Equity) Bill is the first of the three Bills in this package. The Opposition will be proposing no Committee stage amendments to that Bill. I first say to the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs (Senator Ryan) that it is quite ridiculous for her to assert that these Bills are not capable of amendment. The Constitution provides in relation to increasing appropriations that the Senate can move only by way of request, but to say that these Bills are not capable of being amended is ridiculous.
—I did not say they were incapable of amendment.

—The Minister said in her summing up that because she regarded the Bills as money Bills she would not consider accepting amendments. The Minister may think she has some special position but she is answerable to this Committee and to the Parliament, and none of her legislation becomes effective until it is through the Parliament. She should not start telling the Parliament when her Bills can be amended or when changes can be made. If we think it is not appropriate legislation, we will move that way. That is in relation to matters to come later. Whether she accepts them is something she can answer for to a wider Australian electorate.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to ask a few questions in relation to the participation and equity Bill, which really involves the school to work transition program plus $20m. We appreciate the Government providing that $20m. which, we think, if properly used , will be of help to children, and which we applaud. Let us be quite clear about that. We applaud what the Government is trying to do, but we do not understand some of the provisions or why they have been drawn up in a certain way. First of all, the Bill has an objects clause which is not quite clear. Am I correct in assuming that part (a) of the objects clause is simply to encourage a number of things to happen, and that therefore almost anything that happens under the program, provided it can be said to be encouraging it, will be judged to have been successful in terms of the objects? That is not a very good or testable objective.

I say to the Minister in a constructive way that surely if she wants people to participate in education or training until they have completed a secondary education or an equivalent course of training there is a more disciplined way to express that objective. Perhaps it would be better 'to have achieved a greater participation by youth in education or training until they have completed a secondary education'. The words of the Minister in the objects clause are really a soft cop out. She says that all she is trying to do is encourage. Almost anything she does will be, in terms of evaluation, successful against that very soft objective. I ask the Minister: Is it adequate just to say 'to encourage'? I think what the Minister is out to do is more than to encourage. She is out to get results, and the Government wants results, and should not that be put into the objects clause?

Secondly, under paragraph (b) of the objects clause, the Minister says a number of things which I find need some clarification. What is the meaning of the term 'more equitable outcomes' as it is included in that objects clause? What does she mean by it and what will she be doing? What are the kinds of things that will actually be done in pursuit of this objective that the Government has set down? Will it in fact give less opportunity to some people in trying to produce what she regards as more equitable outcomes in education for all young persons? Can she explain, in terms of the objects, just what she is about?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RYAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Education and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —The meaning of the word 'encourage' in the objects clause of the States Grants (Education Assistance-Participation and Equity) Bill means just that. We believe that about 70 per cent of young people have been discouraged from completing their secondary schooling or undertaking appropriate education or training in the post-compulsory years by a number of factors. They have been discouraged by inadequate curriculum; they have been discouraged by a school organisation which has been unsuitable for older adolescents and they have been discouraged perhaps by teachers who have not been appropriately prepared or trained to assist them in those years. We believe that the kinds of programs which will come about in secondary schooling and other educational institutions as a result of this legislation will encourage people. There will be a whole range of programs which will be funded under this allocation.

SPEECH.PARA: I should point out to Senator Peter Baume that the Commonwealth Schools Commission report on the participation and equity program will be tabled next week and will set out in considerable detail exactly how the program will work, the way in which State governments, non-government school authorities, teachers and parents will be involved in developing new programs for the post-compulsory years. Many of Senator Baume's more detailed considerations will be met then. But it is very clear that there have been many discouraging aspects for many young people in the way secondary schooling has been organised, and those aspects go to a very large extent to explain the fact that on a national average about only 30 per cent of our young people complete secondary schooling. I would not have thought any honourable senator in this place would find that a satisfactory situation. I would have thought that anybody who was concerned with the plight of unemployed youth, with the underskilled character of many sections of the work force, with the high unemployment rate, with the need of this economy for new skills, new industries and new activities, would realise that some changes, particularly in the post-compulsory years of schooling, are needed . Of course this Bill will help to make some of those important changes come about.

Senator Baume questioned the phrase 'more equitable outcomes'. He seems to have difficulty in grasping the fact that outcomes in schooling are very unequal and very inequitable. I repeat the statistic: 70 per cent of young people leave school without having completed their secondary education, not competent to proceed to higher education or training and not able to get jobs. That is an unequal outcome. That is an outcome which is inequitable because those young people are having an unequal share of educational resources spent upon them. In contrast to those young people there are other young people who complete their secondary schooling and who go on to university for several years, or to some other form of higher education, and who have very successful outcomes in terms of further qualifications, access to the job market and high and secure incomes for the rest of their lives.

While 70 per cent of the population have very minimal outcomes from schooling and 30 per cent of the population have very successful outcomes the situation is inequitable. That situation is unsatisfactory as far as this Government is concerned. Hence, we have funded and planned, in co-operation with State education authorities and non-government school authorities, a program which will help to change the outcome so that a much higher percentage than 30 per cent of students who finish their secondary schooling are competent to go into some other form of education or training or compete successfully on the job market. That is what we mean by 'more equitable outcomes'. In no sense will we, in providing more and better opportunities for the vast majority of young people , be reducing opportunities for others. Those who already have many, many opportunities will not have their situation impaired by the fact that some opportunities will be extended to children whose needs have not been addressed in the past.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to follow up what the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs (Senator Ryan) just said. Can I put to the Minister the situation of two high schools in Sydney of which I am aware- Killara High School, which is close to my home, and Leichhardt High School, which I had the privilege of visiting recently. The teachers at Leichhardt High told me that the completion rate of students might be something like 13 per cent to 15 per cent. Of course, I agree with the Minister, that that is a very worrying situation. The teachers, who are trying to assist, relate many of the problems faced by students to a whole range of difficulties which lie outside the school. The outcomes at Killara High School are very satisfactory. The completion rate to year 12 would be 70 per cent to 80 per cent. Both of those schools are within the government system. One is performing at a very high level ; the other is performing at a level which requires improvement in terms of the kind of outcome the Minister is talking about. In trying to produce more equitable outcomes, how will the Government approach that kind of problem?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RYAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Education and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am grateful for the honourable senator's question because it highlights exactly what the participation and equity program is about. It is about overcoming the inequities, be they within a system, as Senator Baume has pointed out, between the outcomes at Killara High and the outcomes at Leichhardt High, or the outcomes across systems. The administration of this program will involve the targeting of programs to those schools which have very poor outcomes in terms of completion rates and other matters. As the report to be tabled next week will show, there will be an opportunity for schools with very low retention rates, such as Leichhardt High, to receive extra assistance. This program is not a per capita program. An exactly equal amount or percentage will not be given to every government school or non-government school. The money and the programs will be targeted to give assistance, in the first instance, to schools such as Leichhardt High which have very low retention rates and poor outcomes in many respects.

SPEECH.PARA: This objective and this way of bringing about more satisfactory outcomes in education is exactly what the Opposition, by implication, has been saying for some time we ought to be doing. The Opposition has raised again and again the fact that there are unequal situations within the government school system. It has been asking for some sort of response to these inequalities within the government school system, just as we respond to inequalities within the non- government school system. This program will do that. That is not to say, though, that the participation and equity program will be available only to schools with low retention rates. I am sure that even at Killara High there are improvements that parents, teachers and students might like to see in the range of curriculum offerings. We believe that the curriculum reform aspect of the program will have benefit to all students, even those in government or non-government schools with very high retention rates and, generally speaking, very satisfactory outcomes.

So the program will be very broad. Its main emphasis, particularly in the first year-and I remind the Committee it is a triennial program-will be to make resources available to schools or groups of schools within or across systems. The students are the objects of our concern. Whether they are in government or non-government schools is not of consequence in terms of this program. Their needs are what is of consequence. Schools such as Leichhardt High will benefit directly. We hope in the first year to be able to see some changes and improvements. However, the benefits should go across all systems.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am grateful to the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs (Senator Ryan) for that answer. I am glad that the Opposition and the Government are as one in wanting to see within the government system a response to need. If the Minister is going to talk about needs-based programs in education let us have them across all systems, let them not be confined just to a consideration of non-government schools, as some of us feared was going to happen.

SPEECH.PARA: I now move to some other aspects of the Bill on which we need advice. I refer the Committee to clause 23, under which the Minister is to establish advisory committees in each State. I have had input from some of the States expressing a concern that, although these committees will be established in every State to advise on expenditure, the States will not be able to appoint the members. The Minister will have complete power of veto over State nominations and must approve nominees. I understand that in the end, when the recommendations come up , the Minister will have to approve each program. Why is it her desire to have also a power of veto concerning the people who are to go on the committees?

TALKER.NAME: Senator RYAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Education and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I point out that the responsibility of the Commonwealth Minister is set out in sub-clause (2) of clause 23. The Minister has a responsibility to ensure that an appropriate range of organisations is represented and that such representation shall be of an appropriate size. We have not actually determined what is to be the final number; we are still seeking views from the States on that. The reason the Minister should have a power of veto is that this is a Commonwealth program and a Commonwealth initiative. The Commonwealth wishes to retain a close involvement in it. We wish to know whether our objectives under the program are being pursued appropriately. The relationship between me and the State Ministers will be one of close co-operation and consultation. If we were not to have a close role, such as is set out in the legislation, the character of the program would quickly change from being one which, as a result of a Commonwealth initiative, is pursuing objectives that the Government has for all Australians, to one involving a fragmented series of State and territorial initiatives. In order to keep the Commonwealth character of the program clear and to enable the Commonwealth to monitor the program, there will be a requirement of ministerial approval of the range of organisations and the number of people on committees. The identity of the people making up the committees will be for State Ministers to decide.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me make clear from the outset that the general objectives stated by the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs (Senator Ryan) are laudable and ought to be pursued. My questions relate, however, to the capacity of the Bill to enable that to be done. I notice that in the Minister's second reading speech she said:

SPEECH.PARA: The Program is directed towards bringing about wide ranging changes in schools which will enable them to give all students, and especially those from a disadvantaged backgound, a rewarding, useful education through to the end of secondary schooling. The program will be directed particularly to secondary schools with low retention rates.

No one could argue with the principle involved. No one could argue that at this moment, particularly in the secondary schools-many times I have learnt this from principals-there is a concern that resources are insufficient to provide the kind of pastoral care, the kind of counselling, the kind of specialised programming in crafts and technical subjects that might excite the minds of people. No one can deny that in these schools there are unduly early leavers who believe, however wrongly, that school is not relevant to them. So I accept the basis of need for reform.

I come now to a matter on which I am in a little dilemma. The Bill deals with generalities and not specifics. We are told that next week, presumably after this Bill has been passed, there will be a Commonwealth Schools Commission report on participation and equity. That seems to me to be the wrong way round. It seems to me that what ought to have happened in the first place is that a Commission report should have been prepared. There should have been discussions with the States and some kind of understanding between the States and the Commonwealth as to specifics and not generalities. One should not simply say: 'I have $20m to put some berley on the waters. I hope I catch some fish'. I talk not in any destructive fashion at all. In my own time as Minister I was very eager to establish the transition from school to work and the retention programs . Indeed, I explored the tragic situation of unduly early school leaving, the belief in irrelevance of education to some.

What puzzles me in this whole situation is that we do not know what are the specific intentions. We cannot know, therefore, whether the States will accept or reject them. It is no good the Minister saying, as she did to Senator Baume: 'This is a Commonwealth program, therefore we must have control'. The fact of the matter is that she knows very well indeed that any moneys provided under grants such as this must be determined after consultation with the Australian Education Council.

To put this matter in perspective, the Government says that the money will be provided largely for secondary schools, and I think also for technical and further education institutions. I am not knocking an extra $20m, but this money would not provide for the full maintenance of half a teacher in each of the institutions concerned. With all the best of will in wanting to support grand terms, the program is directed towards bringing about wide-ranging changes in schools. It is important to say at this moment that the amount of money is minuscule to tackle such a problem. Far be it from me to knock back the smallest amount of money which is to go into the system. It is good and commendable, and I would not knock it back. But I am trying to put into perspective what this means. It might mean that there is a start of two things: A much more massive injection of money into this system by both the Commonwealth and the States, and a massive acceptance by the States that inside the primary and secondary schooling systems of the States there is a failure that needs reassessment and re-evaluation.

I can only say, as a former Minister, that, having devoted a considerable amount of time to reforming the post-secondary schooling system, I came to the conclusion that the real needs for reform in Australia lie basically within the sovereignty of the States. At the moment primary and secondary education is lacking some essential qualities that are needed to provide the motivation, the exciting of the curiosity of the individual, the pastoral care which helps people, which encourages them and beckons them and, specifically in the early childhood stages, gives them the stimulation to learn. In the secondary schooling system in particular there is in many cases a lack of counselling, of pastoral care, of seeking out those in danger of unduly early school leaving and a particular lack of encouragement to people who may be inclined towards crafts and skills of that nature. In fact there is a very serious deficiency in the whole system.

There is a need to look at and to challenge, but to challenge constructively, whether this generalist stream of education that now takes some 60 per cent of people to year 11 and some 36 per cent of people to year 12 is really the right thing, or whether we should not build into it as we widen the base of people going forward some particularities that will encourage people.

I rise to say this in no way to be destructive of the system. I hope the system succeeds. Anything that can get meaningful retention of people in schools and not simply hold them in an 'agistment' situation would have our blessing. If we are to achieve this we must, first of all, define the magnitude and the specifics of what we are doing. Nothing like that has happened. The Minister is unable to come to us at this moment and say: 'Here are the specifics of what we are recommending'. She says that next week we may get a report. She is unable to come to us and say: 'We have taken the specifics to the States and this is the result: The States are unwilling to say yes. Even though primary and secondary education are within our sovereignty, we are willing to co-operate in these various ways'. At the moment we have a round sum of money. The Minister, therefore, has some form of bargaining power for the future and perhaps she is taking with her the Commission's report hoping to get some of these kinds of games.

I repeat: I have personally reached the very firm view that there are grave defects in Australia inside the primary and secondary system. It was no encouragement to me to find that there had been, by academic research, the relevation that, of all 14-year-old children in Australia, 25 per cent are incapable of independent reading and 15 per cent are incapable of independent, simple figuring. This is the gravest indictment of our State education systems. It is an indictment of us all that we have not directed our thrusts and energies towards where the real defects lie. If we have not given to our children the hunger to learn these kinds of basic skills, how can we talk further on the matter?

There are worse statistics than the ones I have just mentioned. In Australia, of all 15-year-olds to 19-year-olds, 60 per cent are either in the work force or unemployed; that is, they are out of schooling. In other words, in that critical period, they are not acquiring skills; they are either working or unemployed, on the dole. That compares with two major competing countries in the world: In Japan only 24 per cent of 15-year-olds to 19-year-olds are in the work force; the remainder are in the education stream. In the United States of America only 26 per cent of 15-year-olds to 19-year-olds are in the work force; the remainder are in the education stream. So, basically, we have a peril in Australia. As other countries are coming into higher technology and higher skills we are lagging back. Those statistics are strongly presented by objective academic researchers. Those are the facts. If any honourable senator disagrees with that, these facts were brought before the Australian Education Council repeatedly in my time. They have been published as academic research and have been accepted as academic research.

I make these points not in a destructive way. If we are to move further into this situation as a Commonwealth of trying to get co-operation with the States to reform fundamentally primary and secondary schooling in Australia, let us, firstly, have a specific blueprint before us of what we mean. What do we mean? What are we aiming to do? Secondly, let us have before us the results of detailed conferences between the Commonwealth and States and the goals to which the Minister can go. At this moment what she says are grand things. How can anyone say that it would be wrong for the program to be directed towards bringing about wide-ranging changes in schools? Does any State say that it will permit the Commonwealth to intervene to bring about wide-ranging changes in its schools? Let us have the information. It would be valuable. It would be a valuable breakthrough.

I rose to speak not in a destructive way but to look at the basic objectives of the Bill and at what can be done with the small seeding funds it provides. Fundamentally, if one wanted to do one thing in the 1,200-odd high schools one would need at least a couple of extra people-a vocational counsellor who could advise and direct the students and certainly a person or persons who could give the kind of pastoral care that would give people a feeling that someone was concerned about them. When I brought in the education program for unemployed youth I sought to expose the defects of the secondary system to provide the sorts of figures I am now giving.

The reports of EPUY research are available for all to see. Many thousands of students have now passed through its courses. Time and again they said to me: ' Why are you interested in me?' I said: 'Why not?' They said: 'Because no one is concerned about me'. The reports of EPUY, which are fundamental to this program, said: 'Yes, the basic skills are not good, but something far more fundamental than basic skills is wrong. In every batch of students that we have dealt with we have found two things. Firstly, the students have unduly low self-esteem, have undervalued themselves'. What a horrible thing that the Australian society is creating tens of thousands of people who have unduly low self-esteem and who feel that nobody is concerned about them. Secondly, the reports said that they had unduly low motivation, primarily for that reason. Nothing would excite me more than an adventure into an operation which would find those people at risk, which would lift them up, which would beckon them on, which would show our concern and which would give them greater interest and encouragement for the future. This legislation contains generalities. I do not criticise it for that, but I want to know a very great deal more before we can evaluate it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RYAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Education and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —These Bills, the main function of which is to appropriate the money for the programs, of course set out generalities. I draw Senator Sir John Carrick's attention to the appendix to the program which was attached to the funding guidelines. I assure him that I am aware that for such changes to succeed there needs to be very close co-operation with State Education Ministers . Anyone who has been a Commonwealth Minister for Education knows that the Commonwealth, without the co-operation of the States, can do very little indeed to change education. However, I am happy to report that such co-operation exists . I have been in constant communication with my State ministerial colleagues over this program, since even before the guidelines were announced.

SPEECH.PARA: The report which will be tabled next week will set out in great detail the kinds of programs or the kind of curriculum, counselling, support or whatever for a school which will be funded. I should also tell Senator Sir John Carrick, because he is obviously not aware, that at the Australian Education Council meeting held in Adelaide a couple of weeks ago there was very thorough discussion of the participation and equity program and endorsement of it by all State Ministers. Similarly, at the historic first conference of Ministers with special responsibilities for youth, held in Canberra last week, there was again extensive and detailed discussion of participation and equity, with different State Ministers suggesting different ways in which the program might be implemented in their States. There is a high degree of consultation and co- operation which, as Senator Sir John Carrick's remarks implied, is absolutely essential to the success of the program.

I should say too, that the program is not one that will be prescribed by the Commonwealth for the States. That is not suitable in our very diverse country with its very diverse problems as between city schools, country schools, schools with low retention rates and schools with better retention rates. There is no one way of changing and improving secondary education that the Commonwealth will lay down. The whole character of the program is that it will be worked out in co -operation first all with State bodies and non-government school authorities and then at the school level, we hope with a very high degree of parent, teacher and student involvement in individual schools. So in one school it may be the case, as Senator Sir John Carrick has suggested, the real need is for improved pastoral care and counselling. In other schools, different kinds of needs may be addressed under that program. It is a very flexible program. Its objectives are certainly laid down by the Commonwealth but the ways in which those objectives will be reached will be worked out by a series of co-operative arrangements with the State committees having a guiding role.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs for her remarks. I notice-I can understand it-that the second reading speech indicates that the thrust will be directed mainly and predominantly at secondary schools. My own dilemma was that as I moved backwards I found that the real accident occurred further and further down the scale. I suggest that we all have to be terribly careful, whichever government is in office, that we do not simply use palliatives down the way. We may very well find that the primary accident occurs in early childhood, both in the home and in the schools, and that, if we are to get this kind of remedial or prophylactic situation working, we have to direct our primary thrust to the earliest age of education and to get our best teachers there, because there is abundant evidence that motivation and excitation of curiosity are born or not born in very early childhood. If they are born, a child can survive an even mediocre education and triumph but if they are not, all the palliatives along the way may well fail or not reach full fruition. I am not trying to preach a sermon; I am simply trying to say: Will the Minister, the Commonwealth Schools Commission and the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission be willing to look the whole way down the scale and not simply move backwards towards the primary cause of the accident?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RYAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Education and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would not argue against what Senator Sir John Carrick is saying. Anybody who is interested in the education process is aware that the earliest years are the most crucial and the most critical. If we have problems with secondary retention rates and unsatisfactory schooling in the later years, clearly that implies that there are defects in some primary schooling situations as well. I do not argue with that. I agree that that is something that all governments must address. However, in this program we are trying to address with some urgency the particular problem of low retention rates. We cannot abandon the 15 and 16-year-olds now and say: 'We will start with the primary schooling, and in 10 years time we will not have this problem'. We have to address their problems, but I agree that the outcomes of primary schooling require attention too. I am hopeful that in the next Budget we will be able to make special funds available to address those special problems.

SPEECH.PARA: I should point out that although we know that the results are not as good as they should be in many cases I do not think the Commonwealth Schools Commission, for example, is entirely clear at this stage as to what the problems in primary schooling are. We are now having a joint review for the first time-the joint character is a first-by the Schools Commission and the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission of pre-service teacher training. We want those two commissions to look at the pre-service and in-service training, but particularly the pre-service training, of all teachers and especially primary school teachers to see what the relationship is between the way in which teachers are prepared to go into the schools and the situation they face when they get there. There seems to be some disjunction between those two situations. There seems to be many teachers who are not being appropriately prepared, particularly in primary schooling, to deal with the range of educational needs which they will face.

I think that when we have the results of that review, we will have clearer directions as to how to improve and upgrade primary schooling. It may be that we will want to change or extend pre-service preparation of teachers. It may be that we will want to change the nature of their training. Many specialists in the education area-and I am not a specialist-believe that teacher training should incorporate a lot more in-the-classroom training and that a greater proportion of a trainee's time should be spent actually in the classroom working with an experienced, skilled, mature teacher rather than the current case where most of the time of a teacher trainee is spent in a college focusing on theoretical aspects of education. That may be one of the results of that review. Until we have the results, I do not think that we will have a clear enough indication of exactly how to bring about improvements in primary schooling. I will say in conclusion to my answer to Senator Sir John Carrick's question that funds for this program can be used for some primary projects, particularly those which have to do with the transition from primary to secondary schooling, which is not always a successful transition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was greatly interested in the Minister's statement that a review of pre-service training is in progress. I was disappointed in the report of the Auchmuty National Inquiry into Teacher Training, and I feel that there is a need for pre-service training. I wonder whether the Minister would be able either now or in the early future to give the Senate some details about who is to conduct the review, its terms of reference, its nature and whether it will call for submissions. I share with her the idea that pre-service training is fundamental.

SPEECH.PARA: It is true, that many youngsters who go into teaching regard it as a lesser thing to go into the primary area. Indeed, salaries and wages are so graded. So we start from what I think the Minister and I would agree is a basic fallacy, just as we are starting from a basic fallacy if we think that we do not necessarily need to train teachers in secondary schools in a fully integrated course but that we can have an end-on course. It is a fallacy to think that we can take a person with a degree and within a year teach him to be a teacher. That must be a fundamental fallacy. It may well be due to having subject masters and mistresses rather than teachers trained in pastoral care. Without being too wordy, I enthuse about the idea of a review but I wish to know its nature. I hope that it achieves full results and that it will look at all the fundamentals , including salary scales and creating incentives which would beckon people towards working in the area of early childhood. I take it that when the Minister talks of the primary area, she is talking of early childhood as well and the upgrading of those areas.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RYAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Education and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it would be most satisfactory for Senator Sir John Carrick if I were to make available a short statement next week. I do not have all of the details available today, because all of the details have not been established. I can tell Senator Sir John Carrick, for example, that the Commonwealth Schools Commission group, which will be participating in the review , will be headed by Dr Frank Coulter. Senator Sir John Carrick may know Dr Coulter. He is the Director of Teacher Training at the Canberra College of Advanced Education, and he is independent of the Schools Commission. I think it is important that reviews have an independent element so that people do not feel that they have to be unnecessarily defensive about the prevailing situation.

SPEECH.PARA: I am not sure whether the Tertiary Education Commission has reached the stage of actually setting up its group which will participate in the review. I know that that is in process, but I think that rather than give a partial description of the review now, before the Senate rises I will make available as complete a statement as possible to Senator Sir John Carrick and other interested senators.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have two other matters which I need to raise with the Minister, one of them is fairly brief. I refer to the relation between the existing school to work transition program and the new participation and equity program. The Minister may be aware that some of us have received a large number of representations asking whether programs which are funded presently under the existing school to work transition program will qualify for funding. I understand that the Minister could very well say to me that they are going to be put up by the States. She cannot anticipate what might be recommended. I think that is a proper approach to take. But the question that arises is, either under the interim arrangements-1984 having been designated by the Schools Commission as an interim year-or later, will the Minister say whether any activities, which were carried out under the school to work transition program and which have been funded, would not be suitable? If we know that some of them might not be suitable for funding under the participation and equity program that in a way answers the questions that have been put to me. Does she know of any programs or is it possible to give any of the activities which have been funded, which made up part of the school to work transition program and which, by their nature, might not qualify for funding under PEP either during the interim year or later?

SPEECH.PARA: The second part of that matter is-I just mention the equal opportunity provision which has been written into this Bill-do any parts of the school to work transition program offend the principles the Government has laid down for equal opportunity for people of either sex? In fact, have there been any examples of programs under the school to work transition program which have discriminated against people of one sex?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RYAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Education and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Baume has been very interested in this matter which he has raised now for some months. In fact, he raised the same question on the Senate Estimates committees. I can say only this: Particularly in the case of the interim year, we are in the hands of the States with regard to the continuation of transition programs. Those which the States wish to continue will be continued. The matter was very thoroughly discussed at the Australian Education Council meeting in Adelaide. Ministers made it quite clear that they would make the judgments about which programs they wished to continue. Some programs, because of their nature, were available for only one year. Programs were set up in a trial sense and if the school or the administrators of the program did not find that it was satisfactory or that it involved the interests of the students they would not wish to continue that. I cannot specify those programs because we are leaving these decisions to the States-as I have said, particularly in the interim year. We did not wish anything that was constructive to be withdrawn or stopped. The State Ministers understand and accept this. I believe that those successful initiatives-there were many of them under the transition program-will continue. I think those that did not engage the interests of students or improve participation will not be included by the State Ministers in their submissions on this matter.

SPEECH.PARA: As to the equal opportunity aspect, I think anybody who has spent time in schools, particularly those with low participation rates, would have been told by teachers and would have been able to see for himself or herself that girls are not, generally speaking, being engaged in the most useful educational activities. There may be programs in, for example, computer education; computing is very important now with the dramatically increased role of computers in the work force. If one goes into a computing program it is quite typical in a co- educational school to see a large number of boys and very few girls. I know there are exceptions to that. Senator Baume or Senator Sir John Carrick might like to point out exceptions. Of course there are exceptions. But I think we are very well aware that in these sorts of subject choices girls in particular-I am generalising-are still sheering away from technical subjects which would enable them to go on and take apprenticeships or do computing or mathematics.

I do not think any State Education Minister would say that there was not a necessity to try to persuade girls, particularly, of course, those girls who are early school leavers, to do a wider range of subjects. These kinds of disadvantages are always compounded for the early school leaver. With the high achieving girls who stay on and go on to university I think there is still a bias towards a particular group of subjects, which is not in the best interests of those girls.

The problem relates particularly to early school leaving girls. Even under the transition program there were sex biases which continued the problem of girls not choosing a wide enough range of subjects. I would not like to imply that everything is entirely satisfactory with the range of subjects that boys choose, particularly again the early leaving boys.

If the shadow Minister wants to know why we have put in the equal opportunity provision, it is out of recognition-not just the Commonwealth's recognition but by States, teachers and parents-that either deliberately or unconsciously these kinds of bias exist. They are particularly damaging for the early school leaving girls. We hope that by putting in the general provision-it will not involve a great deal of monitoring-we will remind people, as they develop these programs, to take account of the existing bias in the kinds of subjects that girls do and try to design new programs in such a way that they will thoroughly involve the interests of girls.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am still not sure whether any of the school to work transition programs would qualify. I will not press the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs (Senator Ryan); she is not willing to tell me. Some programs may not be recommended, and I accept this, but that was not the question. The question related to whether any of them would not fit within the guidelines. The Minister will have to approve the programs. All that the State Ministers will do will be to recommend, and the Minister will then have to determine whether she will approve the programs. I remember that this year I refused to approve one program put up by the State of Victoria. The Government wanted to give a substantial amount of money, allegedly under the rubric of school to work transition, to the extremist radio station in Melbourne , 3CR. The Minister reversed my decision when she came to office. That was her decision and her right. She wanted to give the money to 3CR, but that money was to be given under the school to work transition program, proposed by the State Minister. Of course, as Commonwealth Minister I had to approve or not approve that money. The Commonwealth Minister will still have to determine whether programs come within her appreciation of the guidelines. That is why it is important to know whether anything within the school to work transition program would not have satisfied her on that ground.
—I will let you know when it happens. It has not happened yet.

—The Minister will let us know when it happens. I have been very impressed by some of the things I have seen recently in high schools. At Cheltenham Girls High School I saw an enormously good, active computer program and a strong mathematics stream. At this girls' high school there was a strong program in the very things the Minister is worried girls are not participating in sufficiently. I mention Leichhardt High School and Bulli High School. In both of those places I saw girls taking part in manual arts courses, as they should be able to, and I saw young men who had chosen home economics and cooking as electives. If that is what we are after-and I approve-why not?
—It will be useful to be able to cook.

—I hear some comments from my left. I am not sure whether they were serious or whether they made fun of the matter. It is important for people to have the widest possible experience. If that opportunity exists in our high schools, I am delighted. In my own days in high school that was never a possibility, and I remember that those who wanted to take subjects that were considered to be subjects for the other gender were frowned upon.

SPEECH.PARA: I now raise the other significant matter that has not been raised in relation to the States Grants (Education Assistance-Participation and Equity) Bill; that is, what we consider to be the inequitable distribution of funds as between sectors. The Bill provides for the expenditure of funds as between technical and further education institutions and schools. I will not argue that distribution. That is a decision of government, and it is a decision which had to be arbitrary as between technical and further education institutions and schools.

My argument will relate to the distribution of funds-I think they total $44.2m; I hope my arithmetic is accurate-which have been made available for schools. The fact is that about 23 per cent of children attend non-government schools and about 77 per cent attend government schools. Those figures are within a percentage of being correct. It is also true that of those who attend non- government schools six out of seven are in schools in the Catholic systems. Non- government schooling in Australia, in terms of its numbers, is Catholic schooling and the distribution of funds, in effect, will be a distribution between government schools and Catholic schools. The small number of independent schools have about 3 per cent of children.

The Minister talked about retention rates as evidence of outcomes. The retention rates in the Catholic system, while significantly better than those in the government system, are not what the Catholic education authorities want them to be. The Catholic education authorities would be anxious to participate and co -operate in this program, to make maximum use of it and to use it to do the very things which are set down in the objectives. To do that they should receive a fair share of the money. If the retention rates in government schools across the board, allowing for the differences we have already set out today, are of the order of 30 per cent or a bit less, if the retention rates in Catholic schools across the board are of the order of 45 per cent and if the retention rates in the other independent schools are of the order of 75 or 80 per cent, it is not correct, it is not fair, to say that the Catholic system does not need pro rata help. It can use the program.

The Minister will know that a lot of the Catholic schools in some of the developing areas of the major cities are in areas where this program will be particularly helpful to them if they get their fair share of the money. However, what is being provided is anything but fair. Some $44.2m will be provided for schools of which, if my arithmetic is accurate, $4.5m-just a little over 10 per cent-will be going to the whole non-government sector. That simply implies that even if all the money goes into the Catholic system-I imagine that it would not; some would be going to the other schools where there were particular needs or projects-it is not an adequate, fair or equitable distribution of the money. I want the Minister to explain the equity of giving to the Catholic system, in terms of this participation and equity program, only $4.5m out of the $44m or $ 45m which is going to be available to schools when quite clearly their share of pupils might have suggested that they should have received something like twice this amount of money. Even if their completion rates are 45 per cent they are not satisfied in terms of the objectives of this Bill. They have a lot to achieve within their system to do their part in meeting these objectives and the distribution of funds is simply not appropriate and not fair.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RYAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Education and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will explain thoroughly to Senator Baume why the decision we have made about the allocation of funds is a fair decision. In order for Senator Baume to understand that he has to focus not only on the particular distribution of funds under this program but also on the approach to funding as a whole. First of all I should point out that non-government schools will not only have the money available under this program but also they will have access to technical and further education for link courses at no charge or at minimal charge. So there will be more than simply the money appropriated under this legislation for non-government schools available to non-government schools.

SPEECH.PARA: In approaching the Budget we had a number of things to consider. A number of needs in both systems had to be addressed. We had to attempt to overcome a number of defects caused by various distortions in previous Commonwealth Budgets . Senator Baume will recall that in the recurrent funds available to the non- government and government systems there was a bias in favour of the non- government system. There has been a great deal of discussion and debate, of course, about the level of recurrent funds for non-government schools and our decision to engage in some redistribution of those funds. What Senator Peter Baume has not referred to, I think, is our allocation of recurrent funds for government schools. We gave government schools, in their general recurrent allocation, only the same money in real terms as last year, whereas to category 3 schools in the non-government sector, as Senator Baume would be very well aware-the non-government sector, of course, has about 90 per cent of Catholic schools in it-we gave a 3 per cent real increase. So, comparing recurrent funds, the government schools received the same real money and the non-government schools received a 3 per cent real increase.

We then distributed the participation equity funds in favour of the government schools because the non-government schools had received very favourable treatment under the recurrent funding decisions. Senator Baume and, I am sure, Senator Sir John Carrick will be interested in the reasons for doing this because they have both been Commonwealth Education Ministers and they will be very well aware of the problems in this area. In fact, Senator Sir John Carrick pointed out today that it is difficult for the Commonwealth to achieve changes in government schooling because government schools are run by State governments. So the provision of no-strings attached resources achieves changes and improvements only if State governments make certain decisions.

We do not control what State governments do with general recurrent funding. However, we can exercise some influence by Commonwealth programs. We wish to make available additional recurrent resources to the government sector, as opposed to the non-government sector-to which we just gave a 3 per cent real increase-to address the very many needs in the government sector. We did not wish to do this all by way of general recurrent grants because we do not influence how that money is spent. We wished to improve the general recurrent resources usage in the government schools through a targeted Commonwealth program.

I hope that Senator Baume has been following this. I am asking him to look at the pattern of funding as a whole across systems. He will see, in fact, that there is no distortion in favour of the government system. There is certainly a higher proportion of funding under the participation equity program-a Commonwealth initiative which we will be involved with-but as far as general recurrent resources are concerned government schools received only the same real increase. I ask Senator Baume to consider this program and the funds made available to the Catholic sector under it along with the significant extra recurrent resources that we have made available to it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will speak but briefly on the States Grants (Education Assistance-Participation and Equity) Bill 1983, the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Bill 1983 and the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill 1983. I made some points during the second reading debate about the fact I wish the program well but I have serious doubts about its capacity. I think two other points that have arisen during the debate are worth mentioning. One relates to pre-service teacher education. In fact, the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs (Senator Ryan) says that an inquiry is under way.

SPEECH.PARA: There was reference to the Auchmuty report entitled 'National Inquiry into Teacher Education'. I think the Auchmuty report was a failure because it focused on pre-service teacher education. All the research that has been done in this area in recent times points to the fact that the socialisation of teachers takes place in the first two years when they teach and not in the pre-service courses. The real effect on teachers and their capacity to teach comes from other teachers in the teaching situation and not from what is done in teachers' colleges or in unversities. If we are to concentrate yet again on pre-service teacher education it might be useful, in fact, if it could be broadened to at least include the first year or two of teaching.

The other point raised by Senator Sir John Carrick was simply that the proceedings are being broadcast and people might be making decisions about whether they will go into secondary or primary education. Senator Sir John Carrick said that primary school teachers were paid less than secondary school teachers. I am not sure that that is necessarily the case. It is my understanding that in a number of States-I could not say this of all the States- the teacher scales are based on the degree structure of the teachers. They are based on whether the teacher has a three or four year degree and the years of training. The only differentiation, certainly in the government school system, in relation to salaries, comes from the fact that they are different systems. One relates to possible incremental leaps, in relation to subject masters, which are not always available at a primary school. I hope that people who are listening do not make their decisions about which area they go into on the basis that the pay structures may be different. My understanding is that they are identical and that they depend on identical criteria.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —It might be appropriate to intervene now because I do not wish to prolong the Committee's consideration of this Bill. I comment briefly on what Senator Macklin has said. My concern about the report of the Auchmuty National Inquiry into Teacher Education was different . It was a concern about the structure and process of the whole investigation, the way in which the investigation was structured and written and my belief that there was a lack of a single coherent philosophical thread so the inquiry really was predisposed to failing to deliver the goods and study phenomena. I do not think the report really set down a direction.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn to what the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs (Senator Ryan) said to me in terms of funding. This is the first time that anyone has suggested that the distribution of funding for participation in equity, which we think is inequitable, has to be regarded alongside and perhaps as part of the recurrent funding for schools. I find that really quite extraordinary. This program should stand on its own. It has particular objectives within education. I think that many school authorities can be very worried by the explanation which the Minister has given. I do not question it. It is the Government's program and it is the Minister's explanation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I question the Minister's explanation. I am sure that Senator Baume also questions it in his own mind. Presumably what he means--
—I do not question her right to do it.

—He cannot question her right to do it, but of course that is the reason we are considering these Bills. It is important to refer to the guidelines which were presented to the Schools Commission by the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs (Senator Ryan). I refer to the guidelines which were detailed in this Parliament on the participation and equity programs. The guidelines clearly indicate that the Government will establish a new participation and equity program in 1984. The guidelines state:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . to encourage young people to participate in useful and fulfilling education activities will be the centrepiece of the overall framework of youth policies which are being developed by the Government.

Presumably the Minister became selective. The question of which youth will benefit from this program will depend on which schools they happen to have gone to. That is discriminatory. Having said that in her guidelines to the Schools Commission, she is now asking us to take account of 'the pattern of funding as a whole'. Let us look at the pattern of funding as a whole. Let us look at the Australian education budget as a whole-if the Minister wants to look at that-and not merely Commonwealth funding. Let us look at the program of education funding as a whole, at what the States pay and how they distribute their money between government schools.

I know of a number of government schools which are concerned about the fact that they do not get a fair share of the distribution of State government moneys whereas some of the more well-off government schools are getting a lion's share of the funds. Without naming any schools, I know of one government school that has everything that opens and shuts. Another government school and an independent school not far away are very concerned about that. Those two schools wish the other school well, of course, but they are concerned that they do not appear to be getting a fair share of the educational expenditure.

The Government has said-these are the words of the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs-that it will look at the 'pattern of education funding as a whole' . I would be in that like a shot. I think it is an excellent idea to look at the pattern of education funding as a whole. I think we should look at the pattern of the State governments funding of the well-off government schools and the not so well-off government schools. But that is not really an excuse for the discrimination in this measure between those children who have gone through government schools and those who have gone through non-government schools. The statement made by the Minister today is most enlightening. It indicates that at least the Minister has not thought through the logical conclusions that must be drawn from her statements.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RYAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Education and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am surprised that Senator Baume and Senator Harradine should think it is an unsual suggestion to look at the pattern of education funding as a whole. Of course we have to do that. Of course any government has to look overall at what it is trying to achieve in education and at how different parts of the education budget are co-ordinated so that those objectives can be achieved. I see nothing remarkable or new in that. I would have thought that when Senator Baume and Sir John Carrick were Ministers for Education they would have addressed the question of what their Government was trying to do overall.
—It would not have done this.
—No. Obviously there was a failure of imagination when it came to this area, and the previous Government did not do it. But we are doing it.
—It would have shared it out equitably.

—I suppose this argument will rage in the chamber for years to come . Senator Baume seems to think that being equitable means giving the same to everyone per capita, regardless of their needs. We believe that being equitable is addressing the needs that are extremely diverse and addressing them in whatever way they need to be addressed. We are not looking at a simple mathematical computation and saying: We have this number of children and this number of dollars, we divide the two and share out the funds; that would not achieve anything in terms of overcoming special diffculties. We do not proceed in that way. In this education budget or in any other program of this Government we look at needs and we address those needs.
—But even on your own criteria it does not measure up.

—That is Senator Harradine's view. The Government's view is quite different. I think that any talk of discriminatory funding is entirely inappropriate. I have pointed out that non-government schools in their recurrent funding are getting significant additional funds. They are also getting additional funds under the participation and equity program. They have different needs with regard to retention rates from those of the government schools with very low retention rates.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Harradine drew attention to decisions of State governments with regard to their allocation of funds. Of course, that is something of interest to us all , but it is not something that the Commonwealth controls. State governments make decisions as they see fit with regard to their education budgets. We in the Commonwealth take decisions which we believe will assist us to achieve the objectives with which, I am pleased to say, most people agree. Senator Macklin raised the question of the importance of what happens to teachers in terms of their effectiveness once they get to the classroom. I agree with Senator Macklin and I point out to him that our review of teacher training will encompass in- service as well as pre-service training. I am confident that the participation and equity program will benefit all systems with particular needs in a fair and equitable way. We would have liked to have spent more money on this program. That money was not available. But we believe that the amount allotted is a significant additional resource for schools and that we will see very significant improvements as a result.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I query very briefly the question of the determination of what schools are the needy schools and what schools are not. As I understand it-I think I am at one with the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs (Senator Ryan) in this-we are looking primarily at the question of children at risk; that is, children who for whatever reason are finding schooling and the school journey not meaningful and not fruitful and who , therefore, are early dropouts or unskilled. I suggest to the Minister that there is no necessary correlation between the particular resources of a school and the percentage of students at risk. For example, in my State quite commonly these days one will find at some of the schools with considerable resources, even in affluent areas, that as many as 35, 36 or 37 per cent of children are from single parent families. This state of affairs presents an enormous problem to the teachers and the school and bears no relation at all to the sub-economic or sociological stratum of the area concerned. In order to face this problem we will have not simply to look at some kind of category 1, category 2 or category 3 situations; we will have to look at an enormous sociological and psychological problem that cannot be measured by such a scale. I rise simply to ask the Minister to assure us that in any discussion with the States the key will be children at risk, whether they be in government schools or non-government schools, in affluent or disadvantaged areas.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RYAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Education and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I can give Senator Sir John Carrick that assurance. It is certainly the understanding of the States that we are concentrating in the first instance on children at risk. They exist in all schools in all systems, although obviously there are concentrations of them in disadvantaged areas. I do not suggest that there is a necessary inevitable correlation between the resources available to a school and the effectiveness of its programs, but there are some connections. Certainly, when we are talking about changes and improvements we are talking to some extent about additional resources. I would be very pleased to think that some of the changes that we would like to see would be changes that would take place without significant additional resources; changes in school organisation, in involving parents more and so forth, do not necessarily involve more money. They involve ideas, enthusiasm and participation. We hope that the seeding money-I think it is appropriately so described-under this program will spark off some new ideas and enthusiasm, not all of which will require extra resources. As Senator Sir John Carrick himself has pointed out, it may be the case that more counsellors or more people able to give partial care are required; that, of course, is a resource problem.

SPEECH.PARA: Bill agreed to.
Bill reported without amendment; report adopted.

That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —During the second reading debate, I foreshadowed an amendment I would move to the second reading on this Bill. It has been circulated in my name. I just indicate to Senator Macklin that, attracted by the force of his argument in relation, I think, to the word ' absolute' in one place, we amended the wording that he had seen previously. Therefore, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: At end of motion, add ', but the Senate-
(a) condemns the Government for its many dishonoured promises to Australian secondary students;
(b) reaffirms the right of all children to receive guaranteed government support for their education;
(c) insists on the right of every Australian child to receive support for his or her schooling at a level which is predictable and related to educational costs in Government schools;

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Speaking to the amendment moved by Senator Baume, the Australian Democrats are happy to condemn the present Government for its dishonoured promises, as we did the previous Government on the way in which promises in education made to the electorate have been dishonoured; we condemn Senator Baume as Minister and Senator Ryan as Minister. The second paragraph of the amendment states:

SPEECH.PARA: reaffirms the right of all children to receive guaranteed government support for their education;
That would suggest that the Bill does not do that. The Bill does guarantee to all children government support for their education. Paragraph (c) states:
insists on the right of every Australian child to receive support for his or her schooling at a level which is predictable . . .

The level of funding to Australian school children has never been predictable, under the Liberal-National Party Government or under this Government. It is related to a whole range of factors which are unpredictable from year to year. If it were wished to have the ability to be predictable, one would have thought that the previous Government's Budget might have got somewhere near target; it did not. The ability to predict in these matters does not exist. Paragraph (d) states:
supports the principle of freedom of choice in education and the right of all parents to be supported in that choice;

This is not possible. It was never possible under the previous Government. It could not possibly be so under this Government. No government, under its accountability procedures, can give an open cheque to anybody. Paragraph (e) of the amendment states:
deplores the restriction of the free development of non-Government schools . . .

There have always been restrictions on the development of schools, government and non-government. The previous Minister restricted it in certain ways by the way in which funding was provided. These are regulations and criteria which all schools must fulfil. Therefore, we cannot deplore restrictions on the development of schools that the present Government uses or the previous Government used.

We would certainly support paragraph (f) in terms of the arbitrary cuts to some Schools Commission programs and to the professional development program. I am not sure that they are unexplained. I had an explanation. I did not accept it. I would be able to support paragraphs (a) and (f), but the others I think, are simply nonsense.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am somewhat bemused by the Australian Democrats' attitudes. At first I thought that they would not support paragraph (a) on their argument that basically, because the previous Government had broken some promises it had provided a precedent and, therefore, this Government could break promises. Clearly, if one looks at the specific promises on which this Government was elected to office, one realises that it has broken very significant promises indeed.
—I said that we supported that; you did not listen.
—Yes, I did.
—Don't misconstrue what I said.
—Let the Democrats resent as they wish. If Senator Macklin had listened, he would know that I said that during his argument one could have been forgiven for reaching a particular conclusion.
—If you can reach that, that is your problem.

—Senator Macklin can become angry. Every time it is exposed that in the main parts the Democrats simply reflect the decisions of the Australian Labor Party, the Democrats get hostile. But, of course, more and more -
—You should have asked the Prime Minister about that last night.
—Indeed, but the fact is that the Hansard and the Democrats' voting patterns are a clear record of where they stand. This is a classic.

—I take a point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President. I have raised before the matter of misrepresentation of votes of the Senate. The votes of the Senate are for divisions and votes taken on the voices. There is a clear direction, and indeed a statement from the previous President, in relation to our votes. A misrepresentation of our votes is going on.
—There is no point of order.
—The fact is that the Democrats, by not supporting paragraphs (b), (c), (d) and (e), are in fact contributing to the erosion and the destruction-
—Oh, it does nothing; it is a pious attachment to the second reading.

—If Senator Macklin wants to interject, I will draw the attention of the listening public to the fact that the Democrats are angry today because they find themselves in a position where they are going to be exposed as supporting the Government in its erosion of and attacks on the independent schools.
—Oh, you tried that last year.

—Senator Macklin can grumble like a volcano in the corner if he wants to. The fact is that this Government came into office and set about destroying the basic principles of the dual stream of education and no one can deny that. It set about attacking the basic grant in a solid concept. No one can deny that, and this amendment says that. This Government took away the fixed percentage grant which gave every school the certainty, the guarantee, that it could predict next year and the year after what funds would come in. It has in fact said to every one of those independent schools: 'You, the most needy schools cannot in future be guaranteed your funds'. It is very clear that those who do not support paragraphs (b), (c), (d) and (e) are saying that they believe in this attack, that they believe in this erosion of the dual stream of education, that therefore those people who are protesting throughout Australia today are wrong and that they are opposed to the protests.

SPEECH.PARA: I simply rise to put in place what this amendment means. This amendment speaks with the voice of the people throughout Australia who are saying that they are concerned about the quality of education and that they are protesting about the Federal Government's erosion of policies in education and its breaking of promises. It is quite clear where the amendment stands. The Opposition will, of course support the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the amendment. The amendment as now drafted is unexceptionable. One could be tendentious about some of the aspects. For example, Senator Macklin has indicated that the Australian Democrats will not support paragraph (e) because it deplores the restrictions on the free development of non-government schools as an expression of the will of the parents. He says he will not support that because one cannot have unrestricted establishment of schools. But the restriction here refers to the restriction in this Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: The restriction in this Bill locks in students not only at non-government schools but also in government schools in established areas and denies the right of large groups of people who, for perhaps conscientious reasons, will not have the opportunity of expressing their right to choose the type of education best suited to their children. Let us say, for example-I suppose this is something that could be raised in the Committee debate-a group of Muslims wanted to establish a small school in an established area based on the rights of parents to choose the type of education most suited to their children and family environment. Under the restrictions contained in this legislation, they would not be able to do so if the establishment of the school in some way significantly affected either the other non-government schools or the government schools in the area. That is the sort of restriction that we are condemning. The Government can argue why the amendment cannot be supported, but the word ' restriction' refers to restrictions in the legislation.

The other matters have been adequately canvassed in the second reading debate. Senator Baume said, during his speech in moving his amendment, that he would not recanvass those issues and nor will I, but I thought I should at least raise that question to indicate that the amendment really applies to the measure that is now before us. I support the measure but if it fails I have another amendment to move at an appropriate stage to embrace whatever consensus we can get in order to make the Government honour its promises.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is it a Committee stage amendment?

—No, I am foreshadowing that if this amendment is defeated I will move an amendment to the motion for the second reading motion which condemns the Government for its many dishonoured promises to Australian secondary students and for the unexplained and arbitrary cuts to some Schools Commission programs, in particular the professional development program.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs (Senator Ryan) to explain something in the explanatory memorandum which was circulated with her authority. The following statement appears at page 2:

SPEECH.PARA: ''approved authority''-in the existing legislation has been re-expressed in sub- clause (18).
Can she please tell us where in sub-clause 18?

TALKER.NAME: Senator RYAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Education and Youth Affairs)
