SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Opposition, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Page 3, sub-clause 3 (1), definition of ''developing area'', lines 19 to 21 , leave out the definition.

This amendment really is consequential upon the Committee agreeing to other amendments. It may or may not suit the Committee to consider this amendment now. We could come back to it after we determine the series of amendments which relate to restrictions upon the development of new non-government schools. I am in the hands of the Committee. However, I indicate that this amendment is consequential upon other amendments.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RYAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Education and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have indicated that the Government will not accept amendments at the Committee stage. Therefore, Senator Baume can proceed in a way he judges most suitable to him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for her indication. I therefore move:

SPEECH.PARA: That consideration of clause 3 be postponed.
Question resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition opposes the attempts being made to contain and restrict the development of new non- government schools. Our amendment seeks to delete a definition which is a part of the structure being put in place to contain the development of new non- government schools. Perhaps I may explain to the Committee that the Government, by drawing a distinction between established areas and developing areas, and by placing on the development of non-government schools conditions that are different, as between the two areas, hopes to put in place its restrictive policies on the development of new schools. The Opposition believes that it is necessary to remove that definition as part of an attempt to remove these restrictive provisions. There may be very good reasons why parents may wish to establish a new school in any area.

SPEECH.PARA: It may be an appropriate time to identify part of the Opposition's argument. I will take a concrete example which uses the situation to which Senator Harradine has referred. In the St George area of Sydney, and the surrounding district, there has been a big influx of Arabic speaking people, many of whom practise Islam. There can be no doubt that it is an established area but its demography has changed. The people who have moved into it represent a difference in demography. I am aware that some of them wish to establish a new Islamic school. Since it is an established area, the Bill will impose restrictive conditions, in terms of the impact statement that must be sought. If the development of the school would have an adverse effect upon government or non-government schools in the area it is possible that it may be refused funding support by the Government . We simply think that that is wrong; that in fact there is no reason why we cannot continue to rationalise the use of resources. That is just one example which might justify the development of a new non-government school in an established area. I repeat, our amendment seeks to remove certain words which are part of a package of provisions in the Bill which will make it more difficult for new non-government schools to be established.

TALK.START.PARA: — This particular Opposition amendment, as Senator Baume has pointed out, relates to several others. Indeed, if the words proposed to be taken out were taken out we would also have to take out of sub- clause 11 (f) of clause 3 the words 'situated in an area other than a developing area'. The reason the Democrats believe that that part only would have to be taken out is that it is its policy that impact statements should be required in relation to the development of any school in any area. The Government has taken the lesser position of stating that such impact statements need only be prepared in respect of developed areas, so the policy of the Democrats in this regard is certainly tougher then that set out in the Bill. Therefore, we believe that, if these words are taken out, it would be essentially detrimental to the private schools, in the sense that Senator Baume talks about, in the developing areas. If one looks at the Bill-I raised the question previously with the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs (Senator Ryan) as to why developing areas were there -one discovers that the type of issue raised by Senator Baume and Senator Harradine is incorporated in other parts of the Bill. It is possible for a school such as a Muslim school to be established. I am quite sure that, if the type of preconditions that Senator Baume suggested occurred, that is, there was a significant ethnic component change in the population, the types of reasons would well exist under this Act for the provision of such a school. I think Senator Baume's case is taken care of by this. There may be other cases but I think the case raised by Senator Baume is probably the starkest type of case in that it is accommodated under the Act.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RYAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Education and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am grateful for Senator Macklin's comments because they do clarify the situation. There is nothing in the new provisions that would inevitably prevent a school, such as the possible Muslim school, being established in an area where there was an influx of people of the Muslim faith who wanted that sort of a school. In fact if there were an influx that in itself , as Senator Macklin has pointed out, would change the demography of the area and so there would be a justification. All we are seeking to do here is to ensure that resources are used rationally. This is very much in the interests of non-government schools, as non-government school administrators in many cases have admitted or acknowledged to me in my discussion with them.

SPEECH.PARA: It is simply misleading for Senator Peter Baume to suggest that we can have a totally libertarian situation with regard to the development of schools. It would be irresponsible of a Commonwealth or a State government to say that anyone can set up a school of any character wherever that person may like and there will inevitably be funding regardless of how much community effort has already been put into schools in that area. The decisions, of course, are not made directly by me. Ultimately they are approved by me. The State planning and finance committees, whose work Senator Baume will be very familiar with, examine priorities for new schools. They make decisions. On those State planning finance committees are representatives from non-government schools, parents, teachers and administrators. They are very representative committees and they establish the priorities for the development of new schools in any State. We are giving guidelines to them, particularly in regard to developed areas, because there can be particular problems in developed areas.

In answer to Senator Macklin's question about why we did not require the same kind of impact statement from developing areas, we have confidence in the State planning and finance committees procedures in developing areas. We work in close co-operation with the non-government sector. The non-government sector knows that it is in its interests too in new areas to have the planning worked out as soon as possible. So if we know there is to be a new area developed out in the western suburbs of Sydney, the State planning and finance committees know from the earliest stage that, for example, the Catholic Education Commission will be interested in establishing a school there. The ratio is usually about 1:4; say, four government primary schools to one Catholic school. The committees know that they will need to put a school there. There does not seem to be the disruption that one can get in a developed area.

Similarly, if there were to be a school of another character in a developing area, that school's resources can be planned in a rational way because the school knows that it can start, get its capital loan and so forth. But in the developed areas it is simply not a responsible approach to administration to say that, regardless of how many schools exist, regardless of how many resources are being put into schools in an area, any school, without investigation of the impact, can automatically be set up. But where there is a genuine case for a school of a different character, where it can be established that there will not be serious disruption-in the case of the possible Muslim school I do not believe there would be disruption if the Muslims are coming newly into that area-then I presume that the state planning and finance committees would give their approval to such a school and I would certainly endorse that approval.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Quite clearly the Government's purpose in putting in new provisions requiring impact statements is to create circumstances under which some non-government schools may find it more difficult to be registered and to get funding. The situation that has existed up to now has been an almost libertarian situation: Provided schools have been non-profit organisations and provided they have had registration from the appropriate State authority as meeting the educational requirements, they have qualified automatically for funding. People must understand that what is being proposed is a movement away from that situation to a potentially more restrictive-the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs (Senator Ryan) may say 'potentially more restrictive-situation. The only purpose in requiring impact statements is that sooner or later some proposed school somewhere will be found, on an impact statement, not to deserve funding. We are concerned because the clause has that capability and because there is a possibility of the Minister being required to make a determination that a school not get funding on the basis of an impact study.

SPEECH.PARA: By way of illustration the Minister mentioned Muslim children. Quite clearly if within an established area there were a movement of several hundred children from government schools to, perhaps, an Islamic school it would have an effect upon the established government schools-of course it would. But that is no reason to put barriers in the way of the establishment of that school; it is a difference of philosophy. There are those who favour system efficiency over individual parental choice and thre are those who favour parental choice and see it as being something that needs to be responded to. Let me make it quite clear that we do favour the right of parents in forming a school-provided they meet educational requirements and can obtain State registration, and provided they meet the condition that the school would be non-profit-to have access to funding . Of course we endorse co-operative planning. I think mention was made of Aberfoyle Park in South Australia, where there was close co-operative planning, and on one campus four schools were established. Of course we applaud that. That is just good, common sense. We are not against that. We are concerned because we see, in this clause, the establishment of a systematic barrier to some school, some time, somewhere being established and getting funding.

I will return to the amendment. We are concerned about the definition of ' developing area' as it is set out. There is no indication of what a developing area is or what areas are developing. They are those areas which the Minister says are developing areas. The Minister-I am taking an extreme example-could make a decision that the only developing areas in Australia are in the middle of the Simpson Desert. I am simply saying no criteria whatsoever are laid down as to what constitutes a developing area.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a later part; we will come to that later.
—No criteria are identified later.
—You have an amendment on that.

—We are trying to make it clearer what a developing area needs to be. It is totally within the discretion of the Minister to determine what is a developing area. Because this definition may have significant resource implications for people wanting to establish schools, we believe the Minister has to be quite clear-if she is going to put it into the legislation-on exactly what the criteria are which will determine whether something is a developing area or an established area. We do not have that at the moment and very serious consequences can flow to the planners of new schools if in fact determinations are made that something is an established area which they would have thought was still a developing area. For example, a battle is going on at the moment in Manly-Warringah, where some people want to establish a new Anglican non- government school. Mr Temporary Chairman, I imagine you would have some interest in this matter. There is strong pressure from the New South Wales Teachers Federation not to allow that school to be established or to be funded. It may well be that the provisions in this Bill will be used to make it difficult or even impossible for that school to be established and funded. It may not. We want to change a number of things. One of them is the very vague and unspecified definition of 'developing area', with all the implications of that for planners of new schools.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RYAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Education and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Baume displays remarkably little confidence in the decisions and competence of the State planning and finance committees. The criteria for the developing areas will be gazetted early in the New Year. The Schools Commission is working on those in consultation with the State planning and finance committees, but State planning and finance committees have been making decisions about developing areas for years. One of the things they do is to plan new schools for developing areas. I have total confidence that I will be appropriately advised by those State committees. I have confidence that State Education Ministers throughout this country know what is a developing area and what is not a developing area. I have confidence that those committees will resist any mischievous attempt to designate inappropriately an area as developing or developed.

SPEECH.PARA: As Senator Baume knows very well, the Commonwealth does not engage in the detail of these decisions. We have confidence in the work of the State planning and finance committees. They go about their work in, it seems to me, a satisfactory way. Certainly all systems are happy with that arrangement. I have received no representations that we should change the nature of State planning and finance committees. People are always happy to co-operate and to accept membership of them. They will be the main sources of information and advice about developing areas, but the more detailed guidelines for the application of this provision will be gazetted by the Schools Commission after substantial consultation in the New Year.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a very important matter because it impinges upon the rights of parents to choose the type of education best suited to their children. It is all very well for the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs (Senator Ryan) to say that the criteria will be gazetted in January, February or whenever. That is not good enough. Presumably what will be gazetted is the definition of a developing area, or such matters. Clause 3 says:

SPEECH.PARA: 'developing area' means a geographical area that is, in accordance with criteria determined under sub-section (20), a developing area for the purposes of this Act.
What are the purposes? The purpose of this clause is to restrict the establishment of non-government schools. This will be the criteria determined under clause 3 (20), which says:
The Minister may, by notice published in the Gazette determine criteria for the identification of a geographical area as a developing area for the purposes of this Act.

Quite frankly, I think it is quite legitimate for honourable senators to ask the Minister, in the Committee stage of the debate, what she means and what is intended to be determined as a developing area, before we vote on the matter. Senator Macklin gave the example of people who follow the Islamic faith in, say, an inner suburban area of a major city and who want to establish a school. Under that sort of criteria they would not be able to do so. Senator Macklin says they would be able to do so because it would involve demographic changes. Senator Ryan responded by saying: 'Well, I am glad Senator Macklin explained that to us' . It certainly has not explained it to me. What does the work 'demographic' mean ? It deals with the births, deaths, marriages and diseases of population. What has that to do with the price of fish so far as the example we gave is concerned ? It has nothing to do with it.

TALK.START.PARA: —The important thing now is to deal with the shift in population .

—That is the whole point. If we are talking about a shift in population, that does not pay regard to the rights of the parents to choose the type of education best suited to the child. Does this mean shifts in population from one geographical area to another? If that is what it means it is a very dangerous criteria indeed because it excludes the example that was given by Senator Baume. It would most certainly exclude that example. It would lock those children of the Islamic faith into a government school, a Catholic school or another non-government school in a given area.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RYAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Education and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —It might assist honourable senators if I table the administrative guidelines for 1984-I thought all honourable senators would have examined them-which have been sent out by the Commonwealth Schools Commission to school administrators. Several pages in those guidelines describe the nature of development in established areas. They cover many more things than Senator Harradine has suggested they might cover. They cover population patterns, housing development, existing infrastructure, land use and so on. They are quite extensive. I will table them now for the assistance of honourable senators. I must resile from any suggestion that seems to be being beaten up in this Committee debate that we are trying to restrict the development of schools of a particular faith, for example the Muslim schools. There will be no unnecessary restriction but any person who thinks responsibly about the rational use of scarce resources must agree that some sorts of planning procedures and impact statements are a necessary part of responsible administration. I now table the guidelines.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not know whether those guidelines were made available previously to parliamentarians.
—Yes, they have. I have them.

—That is all right, but they are not contained in legislation. The fact that Senator Macklin has them does not mean that all parliamentarians have them, because he is a spokesman on education. I do not know that they have been tabled in the Parliament. It is all very well to say that the guidelines are contained in a document, but we are now trying to put into legislation some principles which can be used and which the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs (Senator Ryan) has said will be used possibly to restrict in some way the development of some schools. The Minister said it is necessary to do so. That is precisely what we are worried about. It is not a question of the particular example that the Opposition used. We used it as an illustration. It is interesting that these criteria which the Minister says are contained in the document are not contained in the legislation. They are not contained in subordinate legislation which has to come before the Parliament. Any criteria could be laid down and the Parliament would have no chance to make any input into them. It is not satisfactory.

SPEECH.PARA: I ask the Minister another question. She keeps coming back to the role of the planning and finance committees. Is it not true that, in restricting the development of new schools, the right of those people to draw recurrent funding in respect of their children may also be put at risk, and that a school that has not passed, as it were, the impact statement test not only may have its access to capital funding restricted-that is where the planning and finance committees come in very directly-but also may have its access to recurrent funding interfered with? If a school has been registered by the State as meeting certain criteria and as a non-profit organisation, is it possible, if it has not passed the impact statement test, that it could be denied recurrent funding? Is this not something that should worry all parents and all school systems?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RYAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Education and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course it is not something that should worry parents and schools and of course there is always some sort of planning and administrative procedure. When Senator Baume was Minister for Education there were planning and administrative procedures. We are refining those to some extent in a rational way. Once schools are established, according to both the Commonwealth and the States, of course they have rights to recurrent funding. Registration procedures will be improved in all States. All State Ministers endorsed the working party report on registration. I believe that rational planning will now be carried out to a much greater extent by the States as a result of that decision. The Commonwealth of course, will make recurrent funding available to schools which are properly established.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Baume keeps positing this totally libertarian situation as if it prevailed previously, when it did not, as if it would ever prevail in the future under any administration, which it would not. Senator Baume cannot say that should his Party get back into government it would have no interest in the planning effects of new schools, that it would have no interest in the sorts of standards under which the schools would operate and that his Party would simply say: 'It is a school. It has funding. There is no accountability. We are not interested in any effects that school will have'. If he likes to say that, no one will believe him because the business of administrating government funds is a very serious responsibility. We have to be able to account to the public for the way in which public funds are spent under the education budget, as under all budgets.

We are simply establishing a more rational way in which the development of new schools can be facilitated. I say 'facilitated' because I believe it is in the interests of communities wishing to establish new non-government schools that there be proper and rational procedures. Senator Baume will be aware that many schools which started without proper planning, perhaps because of some parental enthusiasm or a desire to exercise a choice, as Senator Harradine would say, have collapsed six months later because of inadequate planning. How disruptive is that for the children? How disruptive is that for the parents? How wasteful of resources is that? If Senator Baume is saying that those developments are of no concern to him, he may say so. But this Government is concerned with accountability, with rational planning and with facilitating parents being able to make choices which will turn out to be effective and will provide stable education to their children. To suggest that we are improperly trying to restrict the exercise of choice is totally erroneous.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister, in her explanation 10 minutes ago, emphasised the role of the State planning and finance committees . I ask the Minister again: What role do they play in giving access to current funding? Is it not a fact that the proposed provisions will put at risk recurrent funding for certain schools?

TALKER.NAME: Senator RYAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Education and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —The State planning and finance committees do have a role in establishing rights for recurrent funding. They recommend the appropriate category for a new non-government school and those recommendations, of course, go to the Commonwealth Schools Commission.
—And the decision is made by whom?

—Ultimately the decision is made by the Minister, but it would be a decision which may be delegated to the Chairman of the Schools Commission. Some of the powers of the Minister are delegated. The process would be that a State planning and finance committee would make recommendations, advice would be given to the Schools Commission, then the Schools Commission would give advice to the Minister.

—The Minister has made excuses for certain measures in the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Bill. We are in a difficult position because we are talking about the definition of 'developing area' on page 3 of the Bill, whereas we ought really to be talking about clause 24 of the Bill. I am really flying in the dark. The Minister said a moment ago as an excuse for these provisions, words to this effect: 'Should there not be some planning for new schools?' As she said in a previous contribution to this Committee debate, there has always been some planning and the State planning and finance committees have worked very hard. I have worked with at least one of them and I know some of the work that they do. Now we find that in this legislation it is being attempted to impose other criteria. I have just received the tabled document produced by the Commonwealth Schools Commission. This is the first time that I have seen it. I am apparently on the black list of the Schools Commission.
—Not on the inside running list.

—I am not on the inside running list of the Schools Commission . I must say that I intend to keep the Schools Commission under a great deal of scrutiny, as far as possible. Certain members of the Schools Commission have a set position against non-government schools and it is quite an odd situation.
—Which one?

—The Minister asks: 'Which one'? There are a number of them but, if she wants to know, Van Davey is one who has already put forward, as was publicly stated, the zero funding option. That is one of the Minister's appointees to the Commission. However, I hope to get at least some of the documentation on the Schools Commission and if I find I have not I will be raising the matter in the Parliament. This document has some 15 to 20 pages. I will not read it here, but it is relevant to this debate. The Opposition spokesman on education and other honourable senators have not been given the document.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I indicate that we will seek to divide at appropriate places throughout the Committee stage. I will be interested to see how the vote goes on this definition, but we will not necessarily divide on this amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (2) Page 10, sub-clause 3 (9), lines 13 to 30, leave out all words after '' systemic school'' (line 13).

This amendment raises another part of the unsatisfactory provisions which are being introduced. This sub-clause seeks to provide arrangements to allow the Minister to review the status of a school if it has undergone a substantial change in character. The document the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs ( Senator Ryan) has just circulated-she chided me, in a way, for not having some knowledge about it-says that a change in character of an existing school from a profit making to a non-profit making character would be sufficient to bring that school within this provision. It provides that the school, if it changes its character, will need to undergo certain review procedures for consideration by the Minister.

This may mean that a school which falls within that definition ceases to be a systemic school-this is the section relating to systemic schools-and may be removed from the system. It is possible for part of the school, the whole school or none of the school to be redeclared a systemic school, depending upon the change which has taken place. Of course, that will affect the recurrent support the system can attract for application on behalf of the children at that school. These are quite worrying provisions. If a school, which has been a primary school, starts a secondary stream it may be quite proper for the Minister to say in respect of that secondary stream: 'We want to have some negotiations and to talk'. But this provides an unfettered capacity for the Minister if she so wished. It does not matter what advice the Minister receives. In the end it is her decision to declare no part of a school as being a systemic school and in fact to declare none of the school for purposes of recurrent funding.

The uncertainties in this clause as it is written are giving grave concern to some non-government school authorities and representatives. The clause refers to a substantial change-a substantially different body of students attending the school. What does 'substantial' mean? It means what the Minister thinks it means in the end. The clause also refers to an announced plan for the school. What is a plan for the school? Does it mean that every new school that is developed will immediately put out a plan covering its development from kindergarten to year 12 to guard against the possibility of being caught not having included in some plan its possible extension to a broad and comprehensive educational provision? What constitutes a public announcement in terms of the clause? The difficulty about this clause is that established schools which may wish to alter, upgrade or improve what they are doing are placed at risk.

We think that one of the purposes of this provision is to prevent existing schools, particularly existing Catholic schools, from expanding their capacity, the number of places they offer and their offerings in certain districts. I moved around Sydney and visited government schools and non-government schools. Among the non-government schools I visited Catholic systemic schools. I have yet to go to a Catholic systemic school that is not bursting at the seams because of the number of children. I have yet to go to a Catholic systemic school that is not desperate for the opportunity to offer more places-they have long waiting lists-and I have yet to go to an opening at which the bishops do not advise me of the large numbers of people who are unable to get admission for their children into the Catholic school system.

Parents in many areas feel cheated because they cannot find places in the parochial school system. They want the schools to expand and to add new streams. They do not like the idea that when their children get to sixth grade, for example, in a Catholic parochial school there will be no Catholic high school available to them. I am reminded of a visit I made to Marayong recently, which is in the Chairman's and my electorate. I went to a very good parochial school there and talked to the sisters. Adjacent is the regional Catholic high school which is bursting at the seams. There is a worry emerging that next year, the year after or very soon it will not be possible to offer automatic progression to those children in the primary school-children already in the system.

I move the amendment to take out all the words after 'systemic school' because the words that follow in clause 3 (9) impose restrictions upon the schools' opportunity to expand. It is our belief that we should encourage them to expand, and we should facilitate their expansion. We think that because of the uncertainties, the vaguenesses and the imprecision of some of the words, and because they give unfettered discretion to the Minister, the words following ' systemic school' should be struck out.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Clause 3 (9) of the Bill places in doubt the legislation's effect on the systemic schools in respect of recurrent grants. The classification of a school as a systemic school will be as contained in this provision and the systemic schools will be gazetted but, to characterise the wording of the legislation, if the Minister is satisfied that a school's character has substantially changed the school is automatically removed from the list of systemic schools. We cannot foresee the effect of this provision on the systemic school system simply because we cannot foresee what will be in the Minister's mind in two months time, let alone what is in her mind now.

SPEECH.PARA: A substantial change in a school's character can occur in a number of ways. As is detailed in the legislation, a school could have a change of location, thus having a substantially different body of students. As has been explained by Senator Baume, it could provide education at a different level. It is entirely up to the Minister whether or not that is a substantial change in the school's character. It is certainly a change in the school's character. If in the Minister's mind it is a substantial change, of course the Minister alone can decide whether that school obtains recurrent grants. I know there are problems about all of these things. I understand an amendment is coming down the track for an appeal mechanism in respect of decisions taken on these matters.

TALK.START.PARA: —An appeals mechanism already exists.

—From Caesar to Caesar. What we require is an easily recognisable system in which everybody knows where he is, and that cannot be achieved by the provisions in this Bill. If the Minister can tell us what is her definition of a substantial change, at least we can get somewhere towards understanding the legislation about which we are supposed to make a decision.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RYAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Education and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am surprised that Senator Baume is showing such familiarity with the situation in which Catholic schools in his electorate need expansion. I am surprised that he has not acknowledged the advances we have made to assist them to expand by way of the increases in the capital program and the forward committing of capital for those schools. In answer to Senator Harradine's question as to what is in my mind, what will be in my mind is the advice I will receive from the State planning and finance committees and from the Commonwealth Schools Commission. The Government does not accept the Opposition's amendment.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the Senate that Senator Walsh will be absent from Question Time today. Any questions which would normally be directed to Senator Walsh can be directed to me.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and the Minister for Defence. I ask: Is it a fact that the British aircraft carrier HMS Invincible has been refused dry dock facilities at Garden Island in Sydney because the British Government has refused either to confirm or deny that the ship is carrying nuclear weapons? Is it not standard practice for the navies of Australia's major allies not to declare which ships are and which are not nuclear-armed for the very good reason that such information would be of great value to potential enemies? Have any ships of allied nations been denied facilities before? What effect will this refusal have on visits by ships from other allied nations which may need to use Australian repair facilities?

—A visit to Sydney by HMS Invincible meets the normal criteria for routine visits by the warships of our allies. While HMS Invincible has a technical difficulty which may have necessitated it going into dry dock, the British have now decided that the ship will not be docked at this time. I am advised that the change to HMS Invincible's program was made by the Royal Navy for operational reasons. It is for the Royal Navy to comment on the nature of those operational reasons. As to the question of the carriage of nuclear weapons , it is the case that, again for sound operational reasons to which successive Australian governments have agreed, our major allies neither confirm nor deny the carriage of nuclear weapons on board their warships. Accordingly, this Government is not in a position to confirm or deny whether HMS Invincible had nuclear weapons on it. I add-in case the Deputy Leader of the Opposition has not caught up with it yet-that in the House of Representatives yesterday the Opposition made it clear that its policy would permit the placing of nuclear weapons in the Central Business Discrict in Sydney. That is not something which the Government finds an attractive proposition.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I was really seeking to find out the real basis of the decision of the British authorities not to make use of the dry dock facility. Was it conveyed to them by this Government that unless they answered queries by the Government they would not be allowed to dry dock? Were any queries made by this Government to them in relation to the carriage of nuclear weapons? Was the attitude of this Government in relation to this matter a factor in the British authorities' decision?

—I have already indicated in my first answer that it is for the Royal Navy rather than the Australian Government to comment on the nature of such operational reasons it may have had for the taking of the decision it did.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. I refer to the new assets test telephone information service which has been established. I ask the Minister: Is information available on how many telephone calls have been received by the assets test hot line service set up in each State and Territory? What are the main items queried by people who are using the telephone service? Can the Minister say what proportion of callers to the assets test information service appear to be unaffected by the assets test on pensions? Has an evaluation been done of the effectiveness of the service?

—As Senator Maguire has said, a telephone hotline service has been set up in each State so that people and organisations can inquire as to how they may be affected by the assets test if and when it is established. The number of people ringing up has been considerable. I do not have the exact number in front of me at the moment. Most of the inquiries have been as a result of mistaken views and mistaken apprehensions of people because of the mixed quality of some of the comments made on the assets test. As would be expected from the figures, the majority of people in fact have found that they will not be affected by the assets test. Many of the inquiries, I think also understandably, are about the exemptions for things such as holiday homes and the leisure package, as it has been called. That is understandable because the debate in the media seems to have concentrated on this area rather than on the more equitable redistribution of funds which would result from the reintroduction of such a test. Before the end of Question Time I will obtain for Senator Maguire and the Senate the exact details of the number of people who have used the service and a breakdown of the sorts of inquiries we have received. I believe such a service is a sensible way of providing information for people about proposed government programs.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Attorney-General to the allegations made in the Senate yesterday by Senator Primmer concerning the head of the Australian Secret Intelligence Service, Mr John Ryan. I ask: Is it true that Senator Primmer, as reported in the Sydney Morning Herald, was called in and reprimanded by the Prime Minister for his deplorable outburst? Will the Attorney-General state in the clearest possible terms the Government's condemnation of the persistent and baseless allegations which Senator Primmer has been making about officers of the Department of Foreign Affairs for such a long time? Does the Attorney agree that a clear statement of Government attitude is very desirable, especially in view of comments made yesterday by the Minister for Veterans' Affairs when he strongly supported Senator Primmer's right to go on making such attacks? Does the Attorney-General support Senator Gietzelt's statement?

—Not only in that capacity. I asked the question of the Minister in his capacity both as the Attorney-General and as the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Mr President, as you may well recollect, a security link is involved in the question. Yesterday during the debate on this matter the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation was mentioned.
—I call Senator Evans in both ministerial responsibilities.

—As to the first part of the question, the answer is no. As to the latter parts of the question, I indicate that both Mr Hayden in the House of Representatives and I in this place, speaking both on behalf of Mr Hayden and on occasion, like yesterday, on behalf of myself, have made clear our distaste for allegations being made under the cover of privilege if, in fact, they prove to be without foundation. QUESTION.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, to seek some clarification I ask a supplementary question. The Attorney-General said that the answer to the first part of the question was no. Do I understand that he means it is not true; that the newspaper report that Senator Primmer was summoned by the Prime Minister and reprimanded is untrue?
—That is correct.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Is the Government aware that Father Brian Gore, an Australian priest who has worked for many years amongst the poorest and most oppressed people on Negros Island in the Philippines, is still under house arrest whilst serious criminal charges against him are pursued? Has the Government aided Father Gore by way of representations generally or in relation to the trial itself? Can the Government say what its understanding of the present stage and integrity of that trial process is, particularly given the evident deterioration of the governing capacity of the central Government of the Philippines?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The case of Father Brian Gore remains of deep and continuing interest to the Government which is continuing to monitor the situation very closely. As both Mr Hayden and I, on his behalf, stated earlier this year, the Government will give Father Gore all appropriate assistance to ensure that he has the opportunity to clear his name in accordance with due process of Philippine law, such as that may be. Father Brian Gore was arrested, it will be recalled, on a murder charge on 6 May this year together with Father O'Brien, an Irish priest; Father Dangan, a Filipino priest; and six lay workers. President Marcos ordered the release of the three priests into house arrest on 7 May. The six lay workers, though, remain in custody. Following lodgment of bail petitions on 10 May, Father Gore and the other priests were formally arraigned on the charge of multiple murder. On 17 May all pleaded not guilty. The formal bail hearings concluded on 6 July.

ANSWER.PARA: Consideration of the petition on its merits by the presiding judge could not formally commence until the newly appointed prosecution lawyers had submitted a memorandum summarising the prosecution case. That memorandum was received, we understand, by the court on 7 November. The next step is now for the court to give its written decision. Our Embassy in Manila, I am advised, is maintaining daily contact with Father Gore's attorney. Available evidence indicates that due processes of law are being followed to this point. Father Gore has requested no additional assistance beyond that which is now being provided to him.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: ROYAL COMMISSION ON AUSTRALIA'S SECURITY AND INTELLIGENCE AGENCIES

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Attorney-General to reports that the Labor Caucus yesterday established a five-man group to consult with him and work on a submission to the Hope Royal Commission on Australia's Security and Intelligence Agencies. I ask the Attorney-General: Is the setting up of this working party a reflection of Caucus unrest over the Government's handling of recent incidents concerning national security, namely, the Combe-Ivanov affair and the Australian Secret Intelligence Service raid on the Sheraton Hotel? What status will this submission enjoy? Will it represent a Government or merely a Caucus-Labor Party organisation view? Does the Attorney-General believe that the submission should first be presented to him for Government consideration before going to the Commission?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The decision to establish a committee to work up a submission to Mr Justice Hope in respect of the latter part of his inquiry is not a reflection, in any sense, of Caucus unrest, as Senator Crichton-Browne puts it, with recent developments. There was indeed an endorsement by Caucus yesterday of Mr Hawke's statement and the terms of the report accordingly. There is, however, a continuing concern within the Government Party and the Government about the operation of Australian security services. That concern is reflected in the Party platform and it was certainly reflected in the pre-election policy statements for which I was responsible so far as the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation was concerned. We do believe, as I have said on numerous public occasions, that the accountability mechanisms in relation to ASIO need to be improved in a number of ways which I have spelt out in detail in this chamber, particularly in debates on the ASIO legislation in 1979.

ANSWER.PARA: We also believe that there need to be additional avenues of redress for organisations and individuals who may be prejudiced or think they are prejudiced by reports of the security service. So much was recommended in general terms by Mr Justice Hope and so much is very much a Government commitment. There is also a case clearly for reviewing aspects of the operation and administration of ASIO other than in a legislative sense. That action will certainly be taken in consultation with the organisation concerned. So, putting all that together, there is clearly a case for a submission to be made to Mr Justice Hope who is considering these and other matters. So far as possible it is desired to present a co-ordinated submission reflecting the views of the Australian Labor Party in accordance with its platform. In the event that it does not prove possible to reach complete agreement as to what the contents of such a party submission will be, I will put in on behalf of the Government, as I have always intended to do with the Government's approval, a submission reflecting the Government's view. But at the moment, as I understand the situation, there is very little, if any, difference between the Government's view and that of the Party, not that the latter's view is any business of Senator Crichton-Browne or anyone else in this chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health. Is it a fact that under the present health care arrangements doctors who bulk bill have experienced in some cases quite considerable delays in receiving payment from the Commonwealth? How will this problem be addressed under Medicare? Will the Minister spell out how doctors will be paid under the new bulk billing arrangements?

—Under the present arrangements doctors have experienced difficulties with bulk billing. Primarily this arises out of the fact that bulk billing arrangements at the moment involve fairly complicated steps. In the case of those with health care cards and pensioner health benefit cards the numbers must be matched not only by the Department of Health but also by the Department of Social Security. This involves considerable delays. Under Medicare everyone will have a Medicare card and number and will qualify for the Medicare rebate. As a result, those doctors who bulk bill will be able to have their bulk billing claims processed very quickly because there is no necessity for matching, no necessity to go to the Department of Social Security, for instance, to work out who is eligible and who is not or whether a person is still eligible. Therefore, under these arrangements the processing time will be reduced considerably. The difficulties under the existing system did create problems. The Government recognised this and the Department in recent times has overcome these problems so that now processing times and delays are down to a fortnight or a bit more. Under Medicare the Health Insurance Commission hopes to get the processing time down to five days. Universal coverage will be of great advantage to doctors who bulk bill. As has happened in similar systems overseas, I believe that as the years go by a greater percentage of doctors will take advantage of bulk billing. It will be of advantage to not only themselves but also their patients.

—My question is directed to the Attorney-General. Now that the House of Representatives has returned the Referendum (Constitution Alteration) Amendment Bill, is it the Government's intention to pressure the Senate into dropping its amendment blocking the $1.25 Yes advertising campaign by threatening to deprive Australian Capital Territory and Northern Territory electors of their vote at the coming referendum?
—As the matter is now in the hands of the Senate, no doubt it will be debated when the Bill comes on.

—I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs: How many Japanese nationals are employed on the Iwasaki project at Yeppoon in Queensland? What type of work are they performing? What type of entry visa were they given when they entered Australia and what are the conditions attatching to that type of visa?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs has informed me that currently 13 Japanese nationals are employed by Iwasaki-Sanyo at Yeppoon. Of these, six are to leave Australia permanently in February 1984. There is a Japanese managing director, two contracts liaison managers, one nursery manager, two contract landscapers, four botanical supervisors, and three engineers. All 13 expatriates entered Australia as temporary residents and, as such, must be sponsored by the employer who must provide evidence of having thoroughly searched the local labour market for suitable staff before the sponsorship is approved-there must be a shortage of nursery managers in Queensland. In addition , the sponsor may be required to introduce appropriate training programs to give local staff the opportunity to acquire the particular skills or expertise possessed by the temporary residents.

ANSWER.PARA: Temporary residents are admitted for a specific purpose and they may not vary their occupation or change employer without the prior approval of the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, and they must depart from Australia at the end of their authorised stay. So, six of them are to leave permanently by February 1984. I gather that the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs at some stage must have ensured that the conditions attached to that particular type of visa, which I have gone through, applied in those cases.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Attorney-General. Is the Attorney -General aware of a recent ruling made in the Federal Court of Australia that computer programs are not entitled to copyright protection? Is he aware that this judgment was apparently based on the fact that computer programs are not considered to be literary works within the meaning of the Copyright Act? Given the work that goes into a computer program and the extensive use to which it can be put, does the Attorney-General believe that computer programs should be treated on a similar basis to literary works? If he does, what does he propose to do about it; and, if he does not, why does he not?

—I am familiar with the Federal Court case to which Senator Haines referred. It involved a challenge by Apple computers against the distributor of Wombat computers. Mr Justice Beaumont, in deciding the case, noted that the Copyright Act 1968 extended protection to such technological developments as cinematograph films but did not mention computers, which were then already well known. He inferred that Parliament intended, as a result, to leave protection of computer software to other legislation, such as the Patents and Designs Acts and made his judgment accordingly. On the other hand, the trend of judicial interpretation in the United States has been different, where the Federal Appeals Court has recently held that all computer programs can be copyrighted under the current United States law, even if they are an integral part of the computer's circuitry. In Australia, the question of copyright protection for computer programs, which now assumes immediate importance in the light of this development, has been raised already in submissions to the current departmental review of audio-visual copyright laws, which is in an advanced state of progress. All that I can say, though, at this stage, is that the Department is examining the matter in consultation with the Patent, Trade Marks and Designs Office and with affected interests.
—Urgently?
—Naturally, Senator. Everything happens as a matter of urgency in my Department.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Social Security. How many submissions have been received by the Handicapped Programs Review? Has the 25 November deadline been extended? What arrangements have been made for telephone or Porta-Printer facilities for people who may be unable to prepare written submissions?

—At last count we had received over 1,000 submissions to the Handicapped Programs Review, which is a very pleasing result. About 200 of those were oral submissions, using the special telephone line which was established for that purpose. We have extended the 25 November deadline because we realised at the time that we would certainly receive notification from some individuals and organisations that they would be making a submission but would not submit it in time. We shall still receive submissions that have come in after that date, at least up until the end of the year. The telephone line, which is a toll-free number, will continue to be used. Porta-Printer facilities were established, also on the toll-free number, enabling disabled people with hearing and speech impairments to make their submissions. Perhaps I may take the opportunity for a commercial and say that people can do this by dialling the toll-free number, which is 008-026218. They can, therefore, make their submissions despite their disabilities. We are very hopeful that as a result of this fairly free method of people putting in submissions and the free way in which people will be able to express themselves, we shall be able to get a different perception from that which has been possible in the past through the formal submission structure that has been used. As a result of that, we hope that the Department and the Parliament will have a better idea of what people think of the handicapped persons programs which exist now and give us a better idea of how they should be modified.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: NATIONAL REFERENDUMS: VOTING RIGHTS OF TERRITORIES

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: RESERVE BANK: SUSPENSION OF FOREIGN EXCHANGE DEALINGS

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I refer the Minister to today's Reserve Bank of Australia announcement of the suspension of trading in overseas currencies by Australian banks. What are the reasons behind the Government's decision to take such action ? What is it expected to achieve.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not able to answer Senator Kilgariff's question in great detail, but I will answer it as best I can by describing the circumstances leading up to the decision by the Reserve Bank to suspend dealings in foreign exchange. I am advised that there has been a substantial excess of capital inflow into Australia so far in December. Yesterday there was a particularly substantial daily inflow amounting to about $350m and there was an expectation that today's amount could be even greater. In those circumstances the Government is considering its options in relation to capital inflow and the implications that has for economic policy.

ANSWER.PARA: The Government took the view, in consultation with the Reserve Bank, that it was unwise to leave the exchanges open today. Today is being used to consult with the Government's advisers on the appropriate response to this current problem. The Government will make a statement at an appropriate time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the attention of the Minister representing the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism, been drawn to a recent market survey undertaken by Qantas Airways Ltd which shows that the number of overseas tourists coming to Australia is growing more than twice as fast as the number of Australians going overseas? Can the Minister outline what measures are being implemented by the Government to enable this trend to continue, particularly in regard to increasing the number of tourists from Japan and the United States of America?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised by my colleague Mr Brown that he has not yet seen the results of a recent market survey undertaken by Qantas which are contained in a draft document which at this stage is for internal distribution only. There has, however, been liaison on the matter between Qantas and the Australian Tourist Commission. The Minister is gratified by the results as reported. They confirm the wisdom of the Government's strong support for the promotion overseas of Australia as a tourist destination, as evidenced by the 95 per cent increase in the Australian Tourist Commission's budgetary allocation from $10m in 1982-83 to $19.5m in 1983-84. This allocation included a specific appropriation of $2m to capitalise on Australia's Americas Cup victory. The Australian Tourist Commission proposes to spend $17.3m, that is 88.7 per cent of its budgetary allocation on marketing activities.

ANSWER.PARA: The Australian Tourist Commission has expanded its Tokyo office to include a new product promotion centre. The underlying objective of this centre is to convert general consumer interest in Australia into definite knowledge sufficient to allow informed buying decisions. In conjunction with the travel centre the ATC has introduced a mobile display vehicle called the Youth Market Roadshow which will enable it to mount promotions in any part of the country. The first 10-week operational program incorporated visits and promotions to 21 universities and other venues.

The main promotion in Japan this financial year will, however, be the 'Friendly Australia' campaign involving upwards of 2,000 agencies. Qantas and Japan Air Lines are co-partners with the ATC in the 'Friendly Australia' campaign. In the United States of America, a program of just over $4m has been mounted. This major campaign comprises television and radio advertising, research, distribution supportive materials and publicity. Forty-two American publicists for whom Qantas will provide transport will be visiting Australia at a net cost to the Australian Tourist Commission of $34,500. Co-operative advertising to a value of $330,000 is envisaged with industry contributions totalling an additional $200,000. Qantas will contribute $80,000 of this figure.

Amongst other ATC-Qantas activities has been a special hour-long feature on Australia on the Eye on LA television program. To enhance access to product information about Australia, the ATC is also planning additional tourism product promotion centres in North America.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence Support. I understand that the Department of Defence Support has called tenders for the rework of the air traffic control towers at Richmond in New South Wales and East Sale in Victoria. I further understand that the tenders for these projects close on 20 January. A number of would-be tenderers are concerned at the closing date in view of the holiday shutdown. Will the Attorney refer this matter to the Minister for Defence Support to see whether there is any possibility of an extension of time for the acceptance of tenders for these projects?

PROCTEXT.PARA: Matter of Urgency

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the Senate that I have received the following letter, dated 9 December 1983, from Senator Chaney:

INTERJECT.PARA: Pursuant to Standing Order 64, I give notice that today I propose to move-
'That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:
The need for the Attorney-General to live up to the duties of his office'.
Senator for the Senate of Western Australia Is the motion supported?
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CHANEY
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:
The need for the Attorney-General to live up to the duties of his office.

The Opposition brings forward this motion in the immediate context of the duties of the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) with respect to a case which is no ordinary case. It is a case which involves one of the favoured sons of the Labor Party, the Hon. Mick Young. Of course, we raise it in the context of the Attorney-General having no ordinary duty in this matter, but a very special duty indeed. We raise it in the context of the fact that the Attorney-General, unlike other Ministers, has a duty to act as the guardian of the public interest. We believe it is essential that the Attorney-General both live up to that duty and be seen to live up to that duty. We also bring it forward in the context of a performance by the Attorney-General over the last six months which has certainly left us full of doubt about his having the qualities which are required for the office of Attorney-General. We think he failed to demonstrate that degree of distance and objectivity, the qualities of objectivity and detachment which are classicly the requirements of the office of the Attorney-General. We believe that he has shown himself not to be the guardian of the public interest, but a jealous guardian of his own position and of his Government. We raise those matters because we regard them as being extremely serious and we believe that they warrant the consideration of the Senate.

Ever since the Government became a government the Attorney-General has been the subject of criticism and controversy. He has notched up a very impressive range of achievements in that sense. He started with the spy flights and the most recent matter of controversy is his refusal to consider the position of Mr Young following the report of the Mr Justice Hope Royal Commission on Australia's Security and Intelligence Agencies. There is also a very considerable range in the seriousness of the matter which have been matters of default by the Attorney -General. There is an enormous difference between the importance of issues such as those I have mentioned; that is, the use of the Royal Australian Air Force in the case against Tasmania, the refusal to consider the position of Mr Young and the comparatively minor matter, such as making an addition to his Hansard record when the words did not quite express the meaning that he says he had intended to convey. There is a common thread in those things separated, as they are, by distance and by gravity. The fact is that the Attorney-General has consistently shown, by his actions, a lack of judgment, a lack of objectivity and a lack of detachment. They are serious deficiencies in someone who holds the office of the First Law Officer of the Commonwealth.

There have been consistent queries about how the Attorney-General has gone about his business. I suppose one of the most notable examples of that was his performance with respect to the telephone tap records. He came into the Senate, he answered questions with confidence and he told us that he was answering of his own knowledge. The key point is not that it later came out that he had spent 20 minutes on 700 pages of transcript, that he had read a few pages carefully and scanned the rest-we all know what 20 minutes on 700 pages means-but the key point is that nothing resulted from the examination by the Attorney-General of those 700 pages of transcript, absolutely nothing except an inquiry in New South Wales that, in turn, produced absolutely nothing. Yet the same pages in the hands of a journalist produced questions that brought about the immediate resignation of a New South Wales Minister. What more graphic demonstration could one require of a lack of application, a lack of taking seriously the responsibilities of his office than his coming into this place and saying that, of his own knowledge, he could answer on the contents of those tapes which were in the hands of a mere girl whose qualities as a reporter he disparaged and the examination of which tapes produced questions that brought about the resignation of Mr Jackson.

It would be possible to go on about the deficiencies of the Attorney-General, but it is important to explain to the Senate why we bring forward this motion in this form. We do so because it is important to remember the role of the Attorney -General, a role quite different from that of any other Minister, even the Prime Minister or the Leader of the Government in the Senate. We are not dealing here with a mere politician. Different standards are expected of the Attorney-General from those standards expected of those who owe allegiance to the Government merely as Ministers rather than owing allegiance to the public as guardians of the public interest. In a previous debate in this place I quoted the views of a former Attorney-General of England in a Labour government, the Rt Hon. S. C. Silkin, QC, MP. In an article published in the Parliamentarian he expressed the view that the Attorney-General was 'guardian of the public interest'. At that time Senator Evans seemed to embrace that role for himself.

TALK.START.PARA: —I still do.

—I am glad to hear that he still does. Of course, that is essential, because the people of Australia have to rely on the Attorney-General' s judgments in important areas. Only this week we passed the Telecommunications (Interception) Amendment Bill. That was a typical piece of legislation in that it vested the Attorney-General with discretions and required him to be satisfied before information was provided by the Commissioner of Police. It gave him the power to direct the Commissioner of Police. It is typical of the sorts of functions vested in the Attorney-General, functions which are seen not as functions of a political nature but as having some higher quality.

SPEECH.PARA: We have to rely upon the present Attorney-General to live up to those responsibilities. He has to demonstrate that we can rely on him. I affirm that we believe in the independence of the Attorney-General. There are many functions in respect of which it is not the place of the Opposition, the Government or the Parliament to instruct him in what he has to do. He has that independent role which is so important. Mr Silkin in the same article went on to say:

Parliament must therefore be trusting and tolerant and exercise a prudent self- restraint. But in return it is entitled to ask of the Attorney-General that he will, both by his words and by his actions, show that he is worthy of that trust and tolerance and that he is entitled to the exercise of that self-restraint.

In a sense those words sum up the complaint which I make about the Attorney- General and the matter which I draw to public attention in this debate. We believe we are entitled to ask of the Attorney-General that he will, by both his words and his actions, show that he is worthy of that trust and tolerance and that he is entitled to the exercise of that self-restraint which is cast on his Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), who cannot direct him in his duties, and on us as parliamentarians, who cannot direct him in his duties. The absence of the qualities of prudence and self-restraint has been the most evident deficiency of the Attorney-General over these recent months.

I emphasise again that we do not seek to direct the Attorney-General in what he should do or to express a view as to what conclusions he should draw about Mr Young or anybody else. That is his function and his function alone. But we raise doubts about the propriety of the Attorney-General declining his responsibilities, declining to reconsider Mr Young's position following the findings of Mr Justice Hope, and finding a change in the circumstances which applied when he gave his original opinion. I refer there to the change of attitude about Mr Young's return to the Ministry. That again is central to the case we raise here today. The Attorney-General has a duty to make it clear that he is prepared to consider these matters, that he has considered these matters and that he has come to a conclusion on the facts as they are known now and in the circumstances as they are now, not merely to brush things aside, as he did in response to questions from the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, Senator Durack, and Senator Scott in the Senate on 8 December. We see that as being his clear duty and we see him clearly as failing in that duty.

From what the Attorney-General has said in the Senate or elsewhere, we see no indication that he is currently prepared to play his role as guardian of the public interest in this matter. The role which he is supposed to play in this particular and difficult case is a role which other Attorneys-General have been called to play and have been able to live up to. I refer to a publication which would be well known to the Attorney-General, Law Officers of the Crown, which is published by a well-known legal publisher and written by Mr Edwards. That book refers to the precedent which was established-

TALK.START.PARA: —D. E. Edwards?

—No, J. W. J. Edwards. The example of Lord Shawcross is cited on page 297. I wish to read from that book because there are parallels with the present circumstance which I think reflect on the way in which the present Attorney-General has faced his task. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: That it has . . . become generally recognised that the first duty of the senior Law Officer of the Crown, when . . . an inquiry is set up by Parliament to consider the public interest, which must override consideration of loyalty to the government or to any ministerial colleague who might be the focus of the inquiry, is largely due to the example set by Lord Shawcross. . . .
Lord Shawcross wrote that it was wrong to suggest that the Attorney-General should be excluded from matters which affected his political colleagues, but he said:

. . . it was of the utmost importance from the public point of view to maintain the position that it was the duty (however personally unpleasant) of His Majesty 's Attorney-General to represent the public interest with complete objectivity and detachment, and that to refuse to discharge that duty in a particular case in which the public interest might be suspected to conflict with the interests of certain of his friends or of his political colleagues would be tantamount to saying that the office itself was inadequate to represent and protect the public interest against whosoever might challenge it. It was in many ways a very distasteful decision to have to make . . .
Here Lord Shawcross was referring to decisions which could affect his political friends. He went on to say:

. . . I hope it helped to consolidate the Attorney-General's right and duty-and that is what I emphasise in these matters-the duty-to be wholly detached, wholly independent and to accept the implications of an obligation to protect what he conceives to be the public interest whatever the political results may be.

They are the sorts of principles which we ask the Attorney-General to live up to at this time and we see from his denials yesterday that he is prepared to reconsider this situation as a denial of those principles.

Quite clearly, we are dealing here with Senator Evans's political friends. A quite effusive statement of the value of Mr Young to the Australian Labor Party has been made by the Prime Minister and that statement was repeated, although not quite as effusively, by the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Button. Let us see what the Attorney-General has been asked to consider. He has been asked to consider the position of a man who was described by the Prime Minister in the House of Representatives on 6 December in these terms:
. . . we are not dealing with an ill-intentioned man. We are dealing with a good man and, in my judgment, a very good man, who has made a mistake which he now regrets.
The Prime Minister went on to say-and these are critical words:

He has spent 30 years working in and for the Labor movement. So many of those latter years have been specifically directed at helping to achieve a Federal Labor government, with the totally legitimate expectation of being an important member of that government.

Very clearly, when we ask the Attorney-General to consider this matter we are asking him to consider in the best traditions of this office a matter which is sensitive and critical and which affects his political friends. I believe that those facts, those circumstances, provide all the more reason for obvious objectivity and for proper consideration obvious to the public by the Attorney- General. Instead, we have had from him a blanket refusal to admit the possibility of reconsideration. I ask: What sorts of standards are being maintained when the Government can describe the treatment meted out to Mr Young as being the same as the treatment being meted out to Mr Combe. That was not a claim of the Attorney-General. That was a claim of the Prime Minister. I would have thought that the absurdity of that claim would have been evident to members of the Australian Labor Party who sit opposite, just as it is evidently absurd to the members of the public who heard that statement.

Does anybody doubt that if it had been established by the Royal Commission that Mr Combe was possibly in breach of the Crimes Act that the Government would have said: 'We do not have to consider that matter. We have given it consideration in the past. That is not a matter of concern to us'? The total lack of even- handedness surely stands as one of the indications to the public and to the Opposition, which can go only by the outward signs in these matters, that there has been less than an even-handed application of the sorts of principles that I outlined earlier.
